The commit here isn't a definitive fix for every use case, because every commit in Mercurial is a commit on the default (if you use bookmarks to stack your work instead of branches), but it will fix that error and the 'Diff View' would work fine, just not include multiple commits because the fork base is default.
Since different Mercurial projects have different origin master bookmarks, referring to the compare point of your work. To define a custom fork base, create a file .arcconfig in your project root with the contents:
json
{
  "arc.feature.start.default": "$default_fork_base"
}

. @jgebhardt this does look like an error in the ConnectionDialog's logic. It tries to unmount itself regardless of whether it is currently mounted: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide/ssh-dialog/lib/ConnectionDialog.js#L444
This looks like it could happen if the user closes the dialog and then the SshHandshake resolves after that and tries to close the modal again.
close could guard against this:
``` javascript
  close() {
    ...
var domNode = React.findDOMNode(this);
if (domNode) {
  React.unmountComponentAtNode(domNode.parentNode);
}

},
``

. @jordwalke It won't work remotely because Nuclide's service framework doesn't know how to serialize a Merlin process instance. 'LocalMerlinService.js' acts as the service definition for the MerlinService, and calls to functions exported from the module that are correctly Flow annotated with primitive types can be serialized. Serialization is handled in the proxy-generator.
You could wrap calls to the Merlin process with annotated, exported functions in LocalMerlinService so the calls can be serialized across the service framework properly.
. @jordwalke It works like it sounds like you're describing. When the LocalMerlinService process is requested locally, it delegates to a local instance and does no serialization; you should get a reference to the Merlin process object if you run this locally.
If you want to run this on the server you need to worry about serialization. The service framework is designed to make the existence of serialization transparent to the developer, but it relies on well-annotated services that use a defined set of types that the service framework knows how to serialize.
``` javascript
const {getServiceByNuclideUri} = require('../../client');
// Because '/some/path' is a local path, localMerlinService will delegate to a local instance
// of MerlinService and perform no serialization.
const localMerlinService = await getServiceByNuclideUri('MerlinService', '/some/path');
// Because 'nuclide://some/path' is remote, remoteMerlinService will delegate to the service
// framework and perform serialization of calls according to the proxy generated by parsing
// the type annotations in 'LocalMerlinService.js'
const remoteMerlinService =
  await getServiceByNuclideUri('MerlinService', 'nuclide://some/path');
// Calling methods on them looks exactly the same though.
const localLocation = await localMerlinService.locate('/another/path', 15, 25, 'foo');
const remoteLocation = await remoteMerlinService.locate('/another/path', 15, 25, 'foo');
```

js
onConfirm: async (rootDirectory, relativeFilePath) => {
  var file = rootDirectory.getFile(relativeFilePath);
  var createdSuccessfully = await file.create();
  if (createdSuccessfully) {
    await entry.read().then(text => file.write(text));
    this._reloadDirectory(entry.getParent());
    atom.workspace.open(file.getPath());
  } else {
    atom.notifications.addWarning(
      "Failed to duplicate file",
      {
        dismissable: true,
        detail: `There was a problem duplicating the file. Please check if the file "${file.getBaseName()}" already exists.`,
      }
    );
  }
},

. They can be joined like strings here, but the platform-specific delimiter should be used from Node's path.delimiter:
``` js
import path from 'path';
...
if (opamBin) {
  env = ${env}${path.delimiter}${opamBin};
}
```
. The pattern in Nuclide is to import the path module as 'path' and call functions on it.
``` js
import path from 'path';
...
path.isAbsolute(node.nodePath) &&
```

This is what I know: The Git support should be built-in to Atom -- Nuclide uses a hook to grab that info, though it only works for local filesystems. Nuclide adds Mercurial support with a package, and that requires watchman (https://github.com/facebook/watchman) to work properly.
There's also an open bug tracked internally where the file tree only provides correct reports of version control status for the first project directory. There's a fix ready, so it should be pushed to GitHub soon.

This gets me:

. Still broken in nuclide@0.200.0. This was fixed by ccec96c1c629aa8931df74f2929aa9faaeaa383a. Workaround:

disable the built-in provider (optionally just for .php/.hh files) in autocomplete-plus settings; leave autocomplete-plus as a whole enabled. Nuclide's Hack support includes an alternative Hack provider
disable the autocomplete-snippets package. This one is a bit over-eager about inserting 'where' blocks in the middle of things

It'd be nice not to have to do this out of the box :/. This should probably be filed against HHVM, as this useshh_client --format, which:
 - has no configuration
 - is unsupported (both externally and within FB)
IIRC the plan is to make a complete replacement once @ericlippert's work on the full fidelity parser is complete. hh_client --format for code that doesn't use recent Hack features (the amount of code this works for is rapidly shrinking), manual for everything else until the new thing is done.. An FB-free option would be to extend https://github.com/phplang/phack to fully support parsing Hack (as well as the transpilation stuff, it contains an extended nikic/php-parser), then either address https://github.com/phplang/phack/issues/7 or build a separate printer on top of that AST.
The work needed on the parser is pretty much stuff not marked 'Alpha' in the table in Phack's README. @jesseschalken : ymmv - https://github.com/facebook/hhvm/blob/754e6f649384ccdb6039bfb879726aa1e809917c/hphp/hack/src/hackfmt.ml. hardcoded - but that's the new thing, so might get fixed :)
AIUI this should be an issue against hack, as it'll still end up talking to the typechecker server; a fix would probalby involve the options going into .hhconfig.. https://github.com/facebook/hhvm/blob/master/hphp/hack/src/hackfmt/hack_format.ml#L217 < reference for hardcoding. @ssandler: you can experiment with this by:
brew unlink hhvm
brew install hhvm/hhvm-preview
Then change getUseLspConnection() in ~/.atom/packages/nuclide/pkg/nuclide-hack/lib/HackLanguage.js to always return true (or Promise(true) depending on what version of nuclide you have)
We now have homebrew binaries for high sierra, but not sierra, so if you've not upgraded that'll be a slow build-from-source. I'll try to get sierra binaries/bottles up later today or tomorrow.. disable_optional_and_unknown_shape_fields in experimental_options will get you this - however, this is likely to give you other problems - e.g. dependencies that target 3.23+ may not be usable with this set.. I'm getting this with both the default Hack integration, and when force-enabling LSP support for Hack. Also, I'm pretty sure this is a regression; I remember errors being sorted the way I expect in the past.. The last option sounds more complicated than needed; doesn't replacing the core algorithm with a stable sort basically solve this?. Good point, you're right - memory is needed.. @matthewwithanm 👋 . cc @ljw1004 . Can still reproduce:
```
fredemmott-pro:hhast fredemmott$ apm ls --installed
Community Packages (3) /Users/fredemmott/.atom/packages
├── ex-mode@0.18.0
├── nuclide@0.273.0
└── vim-mode-plus@1.25.1
fredemmott-pro:hhast fredemmott$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.23.2
Electron: 1.6.15
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
This appears to be a Nuclide issue: I can't reproduce with vscode-hack+LSP or vim+LSP. Still able to reproduce with nuclide master, hh_client 3.24, all other plugins uninstalled, and ~/.atom/config.cson deleted. Despite being nuclide-specific, this appears to be fixed in the current nightly HHVM builds - at least for remote development.. Fix bisects to https://github.com/facebook/hhvm/commit/7e8613ff04173fc62e08c58b60c405f4bfd9bb16.
jwatzman:
We're going to open-source idx, so this can be closed :) Tracked in https://github.com/facebook/hhvm/issues/4071
. Awesome, thanks!
. As a workaround, you can replace ' with {"'"} -- lots of Facebook's frontend code does this since historically we just used PHP syntax highlighting which had the same problem.
(Hopefully Nuclide can actually fix this properly once and for all though! :D)

. .bashrc is only run when you start bash. Any changes it makes to the PATH variable only affect that shell and the processes that it spawns. So, if you start Atom from outside the command line, it will not pick up on any changes to the PATH that you have made in your .bashrc. That means it won't look in the location where you have installed Flow.
There are a couple solutions for this:
- Install Flow to a typical location (you discovered this).
- Go into the settings for the nuclide-flow package and specify the absolute path to the Flow binary.
I will test and make sure that this theory is correct, and then I will update the documentation to include this information.

. > [2016-01-26T16:20:05.186Z] [ERROR] nuclide - Problem parsing type hint: Kind AnyFunT not supported
That's unrelated -- it's due to the experimental "enable structured type hints" setting being checked. I haven't implemented structured type hints for all types yet (one of the reasons it's labeled experimental) so for some it will log these errors. The UI for that was either just released or will be in the next release (don't remember off hand), so some types will be expandable trees.
I think the best thing you could do is get the output of ps -eaf | grep flow when you're experiencing this issue.
To be clear, it's expected that Flow will consume a lot of CPU when it first starts up. On the Nuclide codebase it takes in the ballpark of 30 seconds. Then, whenever you save it has to recompute some information. In large projects I've seen this take as long as maybe 5 seconds. However it should only be the Flow worker processes consuming any significant amount of CPU (10-15 of them, maybe). We've seen a few cases where the Flow client processes also consume CPU which is weird and can lead to your system locking up. The ps command above should help us figure out if that's what's happening.

. - It's not documented on the API Wiki. This is actually the first I've heard of this. I don't know if it's a recent feature, or if it has been around for a while, but I didn't know about it.
- I wanted something that I could implement in our LinterAdapter without interfering with the current linter API. Because this either did not exist at the time, or I just didn't know about it, we couldn't modify the functionality of existing properties and maintain compatibility.
- Generally I don't like mixing unrelated concepts. The grammarScopes array is an array of grammar scopes. Introducing a special value that can go in there but is not a grammar scope can become confusing. Even if the API is clear, it's easy to forget that there is a special value that you need to handle differently, and if you add to many such special values it will quickly become a mess. In contrast, it is immediately obvious that a separate property is something different, both to the consumer and producer of the API.
. This is a strange error. I've occasionally seen my repository get into a weird state that breaks the setup script (usually in some npm call like this), and cleaning out the repository does the trick.

Since you ran the setup script with sudo, you may have to run this command with sudo. After that, don't use sudo for the setup script -- it's not necessary.

. @scv119 has a better understanding of the installation process and may be able to provide more details, but from what I understand, our dependencies simply don't get deduped. So, we have a number of nuclide-* Atom packages, and each one depends on a lot of npm packages (for example, nuclide-commons). Because of the way packages get installed in Atom, each one of these packages pulls down its own copies of all of its transitive dependencies. This means that in essence, our nuclide-commons package and any other packages that are frequently-depended-on have a complete install for every nuclide-* apm package. This adds a lot of bloat and results in what you are seeing.
We need some way to avoid installing duplicate dependencies. @zertosh is looking in to options here, I believe.
So the good news is that this is a solvable problem, and not something inherent to Nuclide. The bad news is that we haven't solved it yet :disappointed:

. It is a Flow problem. I've had lots of discussions with them about error position issues. I'm not sure exactly what you're getting at when you say the "correct wrong line number" but I assume you're pointing out that line 39 is correctly displayed in the box? Flow can give us several different positions for a single error so that we can display the context in this box. However, there is no reasonable way for Nuclide to figure out which of the (in this case three) positions to actually put the error at. So, we just use the position associated with the first line.
The Flow team has taken responsibility for putting good positions on the first line of each error message. They have fixed this type of thing in the past.
Oh, and your next question might be "If I run Flow from the command line, the correct position appears on the first line, so doesn't that mean it's a Nuclide problem?" That's because Flow displays errors differently in human-readable form and JSON form (which is what we consume). It's not quite as simple as changing the JSON output to match the human-readable output, since often the first line in the human-readable output is not actually the location you would expect. These things need to be handled by the Flow team on a case-by-case basis.
Hopefully this clears things up.
. Exactly -- I'm not disputing that it is an issue. I'm just explaining why it's an issue with Flow, not Nuclide.

It looks like the linter API has changed a bit: https://github.com/steelbrain/linter/wiki/Linter-API
A message used to have a type property that could be 'Error' or 'Warning', now it's severity, 'info' has been added, and the case has changed. This is kind of frustrating but I think one of the things we should do here is to add more validation to ensure that we are getting the data we expect from providers. We should pop up a red box if a provider gives us data we don't expect.
In this case we should settle on canonical values to use for various levels and make sure we get what we are expecting. We can consider relaxing things like case requirements but we should canonicalize before the message makes it very far into diagnostics.

We have our own interface for linter-like things, called diagnostics. The term "legacy" was just used to differentiate between the two (I think it was a poor choice of word and I will change it).
Our diagnostics interface doesn't poll providers, like the linter interface does. Instead, providers can push messages at any time. This means that it is up to each provider to choose whether to "lint on the fly" or not -- it can't be controlled by one central setting.
We used to have an option in the nuclide-flow package to allow this. I removed it because people kept getting confused and reporting bugs with it. Here's why:
There are two Flow commands for getting errors. flow status looks at the state on disk and returns all of the errors for the project. We want to be able to display all errors, not just the ones in your current file, so we need to call this at some point. flow check-contents takes the unsaved contents of a single file and returns its errors. Obviously, we also need to call this if we want checking without saving.
Here are the problems that I remember:
- check-contents will return errors even for files that don't have /* @flow */ at the top. Since we are also calling status that means there will sometimes be errors and there sometimes won't be.
- check-contents displays errors only for the current file, as if you had the changes in the current file plus everything else on disk. That means errors will be inconsistent with other unsaved files. Granted, I'm not sure how big of an issue this is but some people I've discussed with were concerned by it.
I will talk to the Flow team and see if we can add an option to check-contents to respect the presence or absence of the @flow pragma, and then I would be okay with bringing back this feature behind a setting.
. No, not today. I'm getting the ball rolling on that, though. I don't want to release it until we can respect the lack of a @flow pragma, otherwise it can get really confusing. We got a lot of complaints about this when we allowed it.

. I've added the necessary flag to Flow, and it will be available with the next release. Here's what I'm thinking for the desired behavior in Nuclide:

- As you type, we call flow check-contents. We update that file only.
We still have the problem where changes in a given unsaved file are not reflected elsewhere, but I'm not sure how much of an issue that will be in practice.

. I want to be very careful about making Flow slower. It's an important part of JS development for people who use it, and while it's rechecking it can't provide any IDE features. Here are a few other ideas that I would like to investigate before just chopping more cores off blindly:
- Create a config option with a sane default so that people can specify their own preferred number of cores.
- You say this is a problem with big machines in particular. So maybe make the heuristic take that into account and use a smaller percentage of cores on a bigger machine.
- Run Flow with ionice and/or nice when available.
- You cite rebases as a specific pain point. Maybe Flow could wait to recheck until after a rebase is complete (we watch for rebases in Nuclide and delay work until they are over, so there is precedent). Obviously this one would require changes to Flow.
. Maybe on 32 core machines, but if you have 4 or 8 cores you aren't going to be drowning in IO nearly as much. Which is why one of the suggestions I made is just a more complex heuristic. In your example I think using 16/32 cores would be reasonable, but I don't want to use 4/8 on my laptop.
And ionice ought to solve the IO problem altogether without slowing down the CPU-bound parts.
. > Does Flow make use of more than one worker when just one file changed?
Yes. The number of files changed is not a good predictor of the number of workers Flow needs. It has to recheck every file that is dependent on the changed file(s). I've seen that number approach 1000 in large codebases. There are several phases but the local inference/typechecking phase is trivially parallelizable I believe. If you are checking 1000 files it's going to be slow but you definitely want to throw as much computation at it as you can spare in that case.
I recommend getting in touch with the Flow team if you need a more detailed answer. But generally-speaking we want all the workers we can get.

. Like @bolinfest says we did this, and really wanted to fully embrace the modular philosophy of the Atom ecosystem but it was unsustainable. Our focus has to be on making sure that Nuclide works well as a whole, and when it was 100 different packages it simply didn't. In fact, because each Nuclide package shared so many dependencies that weren't deduped, the single nuclide package we have now is not much bigger on disk than each package we had in the past.
It sounds like you're specifically after extensibility, right? Most of the things you mention actually are extensible via Atom's service-hub. We'd like to make our APIs more stable and well-documented but nobody's found the time yet.
So today you actually can write a separate Atom package that interfaces with Nuclide. The main hurdle is finding and understanding the APIs. Hyperclick, diagnostics, type coverage, outline view, code formatting, to name a few, will all happily consume data from other packages.
There are a few main issues we are currently facing, but none of them are intractable:
- We don't have good documentation of our APIs.
- Many of our APIs should not be considered stable. We should make it clear which ones are and commit to not making breaking changes without a grace period.
- Some features don't actually use service-hub. For example, I'm pretty sure that getting diff view working with Git would require nontrivial changes to the Nuclide codebase itself. In this particular instance I'm not sure that's a bad thing but there may be some features worth revisiting.
So, if you'd like to pitch in I think the main thing that would help right now is documentation. You can take a look at all the packages in pkg, find out which ones expose functionality via service-hub by looking in package.json files, and then submit documentation PRs to the docs folder. It's probably worth opening an issue first so we can discuss whether we want to consider a particular API stable.
I'm closing since we aren't going to split Nuclide up into a ton of small packages (with the possible exception of a few parts like hyperclick). But we do share your goals regarding extensibility.

. I understand the motivation here but I disagree that this is desirable behavior. Showing multiple error messages (a) duplicates information, (b) makes it so that it seems like there are more errors than there actually are, and (c) makes the number of errors inconsistent with the command line output, which is liable to confuse people.
Usually people want this because Flow reports the error in a confusing location. Instead of showing it at all locations, it would be better if Flow just reported it at the best location. In your example (based on a similar example I just put together), Flow reports the main location as that where the props property is defined. I agree that this is a confusing location. However, a better solution would be to have Flow report a different main error location. The Flow team has agreed to treat cases like this as bugs. I recommend opening an issue on Flow or searching for a similar one.
Anyway, thanks for putting up the PR. I appreciate the time spent even though I ultimately disagree that this is a step forward.

bolinfest:
One objection I have to the linter-plus API is that it requires providers to use linter-plus's object model, which is awkward. Looking at https://github.com/steelbrain/Atom-Hack/blob/rewrite/lib/atom-hack.coffee, I'm not comfortable with how Trace or Error is injected. This makes it very hard to write an apm test for your provider.
By comparison, autocomplete-plus does not use inheritance or class-based types. It requires providers to return objects with properties of specific types. I think that is much cleaner.
. I should be able to write a unit test for my linter provider that does not depend on the consumer. If I were to do that today, I would have to mock out constructors for Error and Trace, which makes the test more tedious to write.
This is a real issue. Note that today we have to disable our tests for our FlowLinter because we have observed that tests that have to call activatePackage('linter') in beforeEach() are flaky:
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/9ed0ce4571baa7ba987118903f7ba3d46692191a/pkg/nuclide/flow/spec/FlowLinter-spec.js#L13-L14
This is because linter requires you to get a superclass from the Atom package itself:
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/9ed0ce4571baa7ba987118903f7ba3d46692191a/pkg/nuclide/flow/lib/FlowLinter.js#L13
The build flakiness is not worth it.
Also, passing in constructor functions is not the cleanest thing to do, IMHO. You could just as easily pass in some sort of factory with methods like createError(), etc., that would be cleaner. At least those would be easier to mock.
Further, your current contracts are not future-proof. That is, what happens when you want to start adding more parameters, more of which are optional? Your param list will become a mess. It would be easiest to represent each type as an object literal (at least from the provider's perspective) so that the consumer can recognize more properties over time, but older providers will still work.
In sum, let providers return object literals, and internally, you can convert them to Error, Trace, etc. Things will be more loosely coupled that way.

- 690e0df6b04750c9fe995c89009cd6fcc57ba45f makes it so ./scripts/dev/setup can be run with either Python 2 or Python 3.
- 5903a22d3e0e7f79ea608531f0e37678e9d9c7cd fixes it so it can be run on Windows. There is no need to run it as administrator! (I would actively discourage you from doing so.)
One other issue that I ran into myself when testing these on Linux and Windows is that, depending on how Atom was installed, I might have to run ./scripts/dev/setup as root/administrator because the ~/.atom/packages directory required root/administrator access to write to it. If you find yourself in this situation, I would fix your file permissions for the entire ~/.atom directory so it requires only ordinary user permissions.
Assuming you don't have much in the way of state/preferences/packages in your ~/.atom directory and you're not sure what the easiest way to fix the permissions is, you might just want to blow it away and let Atom re-create it when you start it as non-root/administrator.

. Now that Nuclide is public, hopefully resources like http://nuclide.io/ and https://code.facebook.com/posts/397706937084869 help clarify things, but if not, let me be clear:
- Nuclide is not a fork of Atom.
- Nuclide is a set of packages to add IDE-like functionality to Atom. In particular, we're focused on developing packages to support the technologies we use at Facebook, which includes (but is not limited to) React [Native], Hack, and Mercurial. We are committed to providing open source code that we use internally at Facebook to ensure it is of high quality and does not get stale.
- For technologies that we do not use at Facebook, we try to provide extension points that others can use for building packages for their own technologies. A prominent example of this is hyperclick, as packages for other programming languages will likely also want to provide click-to-symbol functionality.
- If, over time, some of Nuclide's packages are merged into the core of Atom, that's great. If not, that's cool too, since we will continue to develop and make them available as a suite of packages. (We hope that hyperclick will be such a package, which is why it does not have the nuclide- prefix like our other packages do.)
- Currently, for end-users, we provide Nuclide via nuclide-installer because Atom does not currently support a way to declare Atom packages as dependencies of other Atom packages. If Atom ultimately supports the ability to install a suite of packages, we'll happily use that API.

. FYI, it is this transitive dependency in a package.json that causes the issue:


"jasmine-node": "git+https://github.com/kevinsawicki/jasmine-node.git#81af4f953a2b7dfb5bde8331c05362a4b464c5ef",
So npm install doesn't normally need Git, but for this dependency, it does.
I'm updating the System Requirements to reflect this.
. @milesj Yes! I moved our test runner (that depends on jasmine-focused, which depends on git+https://github.com/kevinsawicki/jasmine-node.git#81af4f953a2b7dfb5bde8331c05362a4b464c5ef) into a new nuclide-jasmine package, which is now listed under devDependencies in all of our package.json files as of https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/33ffc40e2d8178f921d4a5319ba70133d659a474.
If you use npm install --production, it will not try to install devDependencies. This is good for end-users because apm install calls npm install --production. However, we assume that developers are trying to develop, so we don't want to exclude devDependencies when npm install is called from ./scripts/dev/setup.
So I'm not sure if this fixes things for you in the developer case, but it will fix things for users who install the prebuilt packages via Atom and do not have Git on their $PATH.

Admittedly, it's a bit of work to even trace through the dependencies to deduce this:
- nuclide-quick-open depends on nuclide-client
- NuclideClient provides a doSearchQuery method that maps to a /search/query path.
- In nuclide-server, there is a services-config.json file that has an entry for our legacy service framework for lib/services/NuclideSearchService.js.
- In lib/services/NuclideSearchService.js, you can see where the mapping for /search/query occurs.
- NuclideSearchService.js depends on nuclide-path-search.
- nuclide-path-search depends on nuclide-watchman-helpers.
- The final piece of the puzzle is https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/b16f67a/pkg/nuclide/path-search/lib/PathSetUpdater.js#L15-L17

. This is a challenge to fix.
The reason why it works locally is because there is a GitRepository object that is bundled with Atom core rather than in its own npm package:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/git-repository.coffee
One of its core dependencies is the npm package git-utils, which contains native code:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/git-utils
So I'm not sure how difficult it would be to extract GitRepository into its own npm package.
If it exists as its own npm package, then we can make it a dependency of nuclide-server and run it there, just like we do with our Mercurial dependencies.

. I don't think we're going to fix this. hyperclick used to do this, but performance was terrible because every time you press the ctrl (or cmd) key, we have to query all of the providers. So if you do ctrl-left or ctrl-right to arrow through a bunch of words, you rack up all of these calls to hyperclick providers and everything grinds to a halt.
So I'm not saying this is unsolvable, but one has to be very, very careful about how this is fixed or it will destroy performance.

. Originally, Nuclide was implemented and distributed this way, but due to some details of how the Node/Atom ecosystem work, this was unsustainable: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8217. This caused issues such as https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/203.

The reality is that we can move a lot faster and deliver a better overall experience by developing in a monolithic repository and releasing as a single package.
If you go to Nuclide's settings, you can disable individual features that would normally be their own Atom packages if there were a reasonable way to distribute them as such.

Regarding conventions, it's hard to say without seeing what specifically you're doing, but a few things to keep in mind:
- Any calls to the file system, local processes etc have to be remoted using the Nuclide RPC framework (since Nuclide works transparently on both local and remote repos). This will already necessitate the use of the Atom Services API
- We highly prefer the re-use of existing abstractions & services (e.g. the diagnostics UI, quick-open, etc) over one-off UIs
- We loosely favor Observables over Promises for APIs, but it's not a hard-and-fast rule.

. This is the same issue as with the internal package formerly known as fb-snippets. Atom assumes in several places that the package directory name is the package name. Working around it at the loader level would only hide the problem. The real solution is to rename the directories of features to their package.json name – aka flatten the directory structure.
. @ssorallen That would be a problem. We'll have to ask the Atom team if we can publish, then unpublish, a package to de facto blacklist the name. Otherwise, the Settings -> Install view would remain crazy crowded (like it is now - before we unpublish).
. We caught this same issue internally with someone running file-watcher. The plan is to flatten /pkg so each directory is the actual feature name. Since I don't think hg will rebase file moves, we'll have to see how many outstanding diffs there are to figure when the least disruptive time is for this codemod.
. The fix should come out this week. The work around is to deactivate the package whose name is conflicting. In the case of the OP, he must have a package called "blame" that once deactivated allows nuclide to start. Whatever the error message is, the name after the "nuclide-" is the conflicting package.
. I apologize for the hold up on this. The workaround is to disable whatever package you have installed that matches one of these directory names https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/tree/master/pkg/nuclide. Then if you don't want that particular Nuclide feature, disable it from Settings -> Packages -> nuclide -> Settings -> 'Enable the "xxx" feature', then re-enable the package that clashed with the name.
The real fix for this won't be in tomorrows release, but may be in the following one.

. @rulatir I'm seeing that after the update is complete. Reloading Atom seems to make everything work again. Have you tried that?
. This can happen for multiple reasons. The reason for it happening immediately after an upgrade, but not after restarting Atom, is because when Atom updates a package, it doesn't actually clear the require cache. So unless very specific conditions are met, you end up loading the same modules as pre-update from memory but with a different disk layout.
The solution we're going to implement, which is similar to VS Code's, is to require a restarting the editor after an upgrade. In the case of Nuclide, we won't force you to reload, but the update will refuse to load until you've restarted (showing you a notification of course).

. flow-bin and the wrapper script solve different problems, and we should support both - as in they work with Nuclide and the Flow team maintains them.
flow-bin
The security problem is easy to overcome. Nuclide can have a list of blessed checksums, that we regularly update as flow versions come out. Before running flow-bin/flow, we verify the checksum, and either refuse to run it if it doesn't match, or warn the user and ask for permission.
My problem with flow-bin is that it downloads the flow binary instead of shipping with it. This has has problems:
- it doesn't use npm's proxy settings (so it complicates installs in envs like Sandcastle),
- it doesn't install if you have ignore-scripts=true,
- the deps it needs to download flow are larger than the flow bins themselves, so installs are fat and take longer than necessary.
IMHO, flow-bin should just package all the platform bins, and skip the download.
The wrapper script
I wanted to open source it but legal issues. I have it sitting in a private repo ready to be published to npm. It's more-or-less the script we used internally (before it supported semver), and a publishing script that downloads all the flow versions for all platforms before packaging. The idea was that you'd run npm -g install flow-versions, it would be a (currently) ~250mb install, but then you'd have a script in /usr/local/bin/flow that works in any setup.
The wrapper script is not for everyone (given how large it is). I see it as a compliment to flow-bin. Akin to having a global eslint install.

. @bitranch, from the Atom console (in the devtools), does process.env.SHELL match the shell you have configured to setup the right PATH? If not, then that's your issue. Atom shells out to your default shell, reads the environment, and patches itself. So if for example, you use zsh and your PATH is set in a .zshrc, but the OS thinks your default is bash - then Atom won't start the right shell, and you won't have the right PATH.

To check your setup you should be able to do the buck quickstart (for iOS, Android, or both) and it will create a working app that builds with Buck. Opening that directory with Nuclide should show the build toolbar and building from within Nuclide should work. Note that the quickstart isn't a RN app though.
. I know the React Native support was being rewritten a bit ago to be more robust (for example, integrating better with the RN packager), which is why Facebook hasn't been pushing Nuclide + Buck as the default/best way to build React Native apps yet.
. It is my understanding that in the near future Buck+Nuclide will be the preferred (but not the only) way to build RN apps[1]. For now I would follow the generic RN directions, which means you'll have to juggle Xcode, Chrome, and an editor like Nuclide unfortunately (that is, no Buck integration).
Nuclide does provide a lot of value in this situation over a stock Atom or a Sublime or Xcode-only, as it has all the Flow/JS goodies (click to symbol, autocomplete, etc) and talks to clang to get the same goodies for ObjC.
The main thing it doesn't have is rebuilding native code automatically in Nuclide (as that requires Buck), which is why you'd need Xcode to press the build button or use xcodebuild from the CLI. When editing just JS, the default RN packager should see when you save JS code in Nuclide and reload the JS bundle in the app, so the JS "build" works today. Removing the need to run builds via Xcode or the packager via the CLI is the work that has been happening to make everything plug and play (for example, see https://github.com/facebook/buck/commit/60ccc96ee20640ba2c32cb16b22e8da694a6379f).
Nuclide even has a native debugger UI so that isn't needed in Xcode (ObjC) or Chrome (JS), though I am not sure it is turned on yet for everyone.
@mkonicek and @jamesgpearce may have more info or suggestions!

Hi @sronsiek, the gutter highlighting is actually provided by Atom's 'git-diff' package (https://github.com/atom/git-diff), which expects certain methods in the relevant "Repository" class to be synchronous. In Nuclide's implementation of HgRepositoryClient (the analogous class to Atom's GitRepository), we do our data fetching asynchronously and triggered by certain events, so the gutter highlighting may not work as expected.
More detail here: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/tree/master/pkg/nuclide/hg-repository#api-caveats

. js-hyperclick uses babel to parse the files. It collects the set of scopes, references to external modules (import and require()), and exports (module.exports =, export, and export default). To avoid constant parsing it holds an internal cache that is invalidated on onDidStopChanging and is only recreated the first time hyperclick requests a suggestion on something that might be an identifier when the grammer is JavaScript.

Yeah, I wanted to add some dynamic nature to WS definitions. Unfortunately I never got to doing that. Also, it's somewhat tricky to do properly and a lot needs to be considered like:
  - How does one name this WS, we don't have a notion of a currently active task.
  - Several or none WS can be active at any point of time, which one is to be updated?
  - What if there are multiple windows open.
    - They can have some shared projects mounted in them, or not, or one can be a descendant of some mounted in the other. WS are stored in the global configuration, having one window update others may lead to unintuitive UI (which, unfortunately, is already happening in some cases with WS).
  - One natural way of assigning a WS to an activity would be by associating with the source control state (branch, bookmark), but these things are optional, somewhat expensive to recompute, to track and also come with their share of problems.
    - What happens when a user updates to a different changeset in the repository?
    - What if the revision is rebased on top of something else.
Again, though, that is not to say that a dynamically declaring WS is not something that needs to be done, just that given the amount of corner cases to consider it is not something trivial.. Looking into it now.. @Alhadis so from browsing the source it seems that file-icons uses synchronous fs as part of its icon determination flow. With Nuclide this would be a non-starter, as one of the main focus areas for Nuclide is support for remote editing (on a remote host, that is). So all of our fs interactions are written with remote in mind.
Nuclide is also expected to work with trees of huge repositories, thousands of elements. For that purpose the rendering of the file-tree rendering is windowed. I suspect that adding any degree of complex logic to the rendering process would degrade performance significantly. Current approach in the file-tree is that everything that can be decided ahead of the rendering is, all data is kept in an immutable hierarchical data structure and the rendering is straightforward process from that structure.. . NODE_ENV is not defined in my shell. Atom sets it to production on first start. So here's the culprit:
A new feature in Atom 1.8.0 is that atom overwrites the env vars when you start it from the shell with the ones that are present in the shell. What happens:
1. You start atom and it sets sensible defaults
2. You open another file from the shell and it overwrites those sensible defaults with whatever is set in your shell.
That's not a problem usually. Most of the time you actually want things like PATH to update.
In my opinion react should run in production mode unless NODE_ENV=development and not run in development mode unless NODE_ENV=production. It just seems too common that NODE_ENV is not set in an interactive shell. On the other hand: Why should react care about this specific use case? Most of the time it runs in a web browser where no one is overwriting process.env (which is probably set by webpack oder browserify).
Just for clarification, there seems to be a bug within react that produces theses errors, but fixing this is not fixing the underlying issue. Using atom from the command line while Atom is already open throws react in development mode (unless you export NODE_ENV=production), thus slowing down Atom as a whole. Not sure who's responsible for a fix in this case 😕

appsforartists:
:+1: 
This would simplify remote connections (as you wouldn't need to manually forward additional ports if you have an especially hardened SSH configuration).  It would also add peace of mind.
I just manually logged nuclide-remote-connection to see if my connection was secure or not.  Thankfully, it is.  However at a glance, it appears that the connection silently falls back to unsecure if it can't find a certificate.  I haven't looked closely enough to see under what conditions that occurs, but that it's even an option is a bit scary.
I'm not a security engineer, so I don't feel confident auditing nuclide-remote as it is.  I'm presuming that the https web socket + the Mac firewall provides a reasonable amount of protection against intrusion.  (After all, it's a core part of FB's infrastructure.)  Then again, I know that ssh has been a trusted standard in security for a very long time, and that a lot of people have invested a lot of effort making and keeping it secure.  I'd be much more comfortable using and recommending Nuclide if all its traffic traveled over its SSH connection.

mreschke:
I didn't want to open port 9090 either.  Found if I use localhost in nuclide server connection instead of actual remote IP, then SSH port forward 9090 it works perfectly.
So lets say my remote server is at server.example.com and it ONLY has port 22 open.
On that remote server, I have a nodejs app running on port 3000.
On my macbook run
ssh -p 22 server.example.com -L 20022:localhost:22 -L 3000:localhost:3000 -L 9090:localhost:9090
Now in nuclide, open new remote connection dialog
server: localhost
port: 20022
So SSHing to localhost:20022 actually SSHs into server.example.com:22 and localhost:9090 is forwarded over to the server along with 3000.  Now watchman works perfectly on 9090 and I can access my nodejs app on my macbook at http://localhost:3000

. @nmote I have some updates:
- The high cpu usage is most likely an issue with Atom and not Nuclide-Flow, as I've had the problem from time to time, even after disabling nuclide-flow. It seems to be connected to the Settings screen. Earlier, this problem seemed to be happening when Nuclide-flow was enabled, and so the co-incidences fooled me.
- Linting: After the very latest update, linting works. It feels like Lint on Fly doesn't work. As I type, the errors that show up reflect the state of the last save, and not what is on-screen. To make matters worse, linter doesn't update anything on save.
  For example, let's say there is a flow error when I save a file. After that as I type, the error will stay even if I fix the error. The error will stay when I save the fix. But will then disappear when I type something.
- Autocomplete: This feature has been hit or miss from the very beginning, but this is probably an issue with flow or autocomplete plus. I get good autocomplete for complex types like promises, but not for simple types like numbers and strings. This is true for ide-flow as well. There is an option in the Api for autocomplete plus that lets you hide lower priority options. So it's possible some other package is hiding the suggestions from Nuclide-flow
- Type Hints on hover have never worked for with Nuclide.
- Go-to-Symbol definition, sometimes works, but only with my own custom keyboard shortcut. Atom doesn't seem to like overriding cmd+click.
. Quick update: While working on my own linter plug-in, (which works almost flawlessly now!) I've added support for traces. Best example of Traces is with the render method annotated with ReactElement.
When you return null from such a method, flow, correctly, complains. But it also points to the type definition of ReactElement as a trace. The actual error message is broken up between the main error and the trace.
Nuclide-flow currently just concats the error string together, but otherwise ignore the trace. Since it would only require changes to a single file, I'll make a patch to fix this in Nuclide.

. Please open up the command line and do
apm search nuclide
You will see a bunch of nuclide-packages. Install them with apm itself. Nuclide-installed and Atom's UI can take multiple days to do it all correctly.
Be mindful that certain packages are definitely not supported on Windows — Nuclide-flow won't work since Flow isn't supported on Windows.
I'm not sure about Hack and other packages. Without Flow however, you will get no autocomplete, typehints etc. So Nuclide is of little use on Windows. You may get Hack Remote development to work, perhaps.
. Could either of you tell me if you did anything special when installing Nuclide to get tool-tips working? Any dependencies? I have not been able get tooltips working at all.
. @phorust Flow works just fine for me. I get linting errors and autocomplete, but not typehints. Just wanted to make sure there wasn't a dependency I was missing.
. There are packages in Nuclide that don't work on Windows. Flow for example only works on OS X and Linux systems. That may be causing some issues.
Further, did you install the packages using the atom UI or with apm ?
Use APM to install all Nuclide-* packages before you open up atom and you should see better results. Atom itself has some serious issues when you open up the settings screen.
. There is also the reactiflux slack team that may make sense.
. @nmote I actually did a little code reformatting to match the style after running it. May have made a mistake. Let me see.
. Should be fixed now. Sorry again.
. Just pushed more changes. Here's some info that might help you avoid wasting time:
1. I added an eslintrc file to help me catch styling problems, and added the missing semi-colons, removed trailing spaces, and add dangling commas
1a. I made dangling commas mandatory, which meant I had to add a few dangling commas where they didn't exist before.
2. I Used setup script and tested that the errors work correctly in Atom
3. I Updated the tests to test the code correctly -
3a. Errors are not always of the type 'Error', they are either 'error' or 'warning' which is taken directly from the flow diagnostic. I have tested that the lower-case strings work fine with AtomLinter
3b. I changed the last test to check for the trace array being present on the object.
Other stuff:
1. I added a couple of flow type definitions in the file to be a stricter type check for diagnostic objects
2. I would like to commit the .eslintrc file to help future contributors, let me know if that is OK.
This is the eslintrc file I'm using —
js
{
  "parser": "babel-eslint",
  "env": {
    "browser": true,
    "node": true,
    "es6": true
  },

    "space-after-keywords": [2, "always"]
  },
  "globals": {
    "TextEditor": false // used for imported type definitions.
  }
}

IanVS:
This can probably be closed now, ya?. I assume this can be closed now, right?. Try alt+cmd+click.  By default, cmd+click will use flow to take you to a definition.. This seems to have been added in the latest version, 0.263.0
I think it might have something to do with this:

Flow
Other occurrences of the local variable under your cursor will now be highlighted.

It looks like restoring the option has already been addressed in a recent commit: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/7355af7895c53dc789c49a8c947e1a357c177ce8
Perhaps it's a setting that only works with recent versions of flow, and older versions have this unfortunate behavior of highlighting the entire block of code?. I think this should be re-opened.  The workaround is great, but the view should be fixed for everyone.  It's so hard to tell what files are inside folders now.. It looks like this may be fixed by https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/3704e5b1bb409f120e241b74272e2f6472e808a2.. @tjfryan it looks like you reviewed https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/78255d804d81d7ccdfd213626a8cf35b36860355 which removed git-diff, and https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/405805af1fc7733c2fac6e893709e074d2a6bc9b which seems to attempt to add new ones?  But it seems the new ones aren't working, is there something we have to do to turn them on?  I can't find Shan Phylim (who made the commits) in github…  Unless maybe it's @shanpls?. This doesn't seem to be fixed in 0.362.0, I still don't have git diff gutters.. @Boboss74 that's strange, it seems to be working for me in 0.366.0.  I restarted atom, and git-diff is still enabled (I've been manually enabling it each time I restart atom).. Perhaps this is related to https://github.com/facebook-atom/atom-ide-ui/issues/144?  Is nuclide only using the first scope?  The scopes I'm getting on that file are:
source.flow
source.js. It seems that in atom 1.33.0-beta1, the source.js scope is no longer included at all in files using flow, which also happened to break all my snippets.  (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/18398). Yes, you can add source.flow to the list of scopes to lint in the linter-eslint settings.  In the next release of linter-eslint, it will be included by default.. This seems to be the commit which broke nuclide for non-facebook users:
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/22eea032f97ba3f724a8f98b62431c6d398286df

cc @kyldvs
. Hey look, a "Close Issue" button. :tada:  :smile: 
. Basic functionality for remote projects appears to work on Windows. I'm using Windows 10 on the client side and Debian Linux on the server side. I can see the directory tree, edit remote files, and files are automatically reloaded if I edit them directly on the server. I haven't tested the more advanced IDE-like functionality such as Flow/Hack integration, but I imagine these would be fine as they execute on the remote server rather than the local machine.
On the other hand, adding local project folders is totally broken. Nothing happens after clicking Add Project Folder and selecting a folder. The console has no errors, either.
@mostafaeweda It seems like it'd be useful to have separate Github issues to track each Windows issue individually, rather than just having this one master issue for Windows support.
. Nuclide seems to run pretty well on Windows now. I've been using it for all
my day-to-day work at Facebook (I'm not on the Nuclide team, I'm just an
end user of Nuclide). I haven't encountered any major issues and for the
most part it seems quite usable.
Almost all of my work is done on a remote Linux server though, so I haven't
really tested Nuclide with local projects. There may be issues with
Hack/Flow for local projects as opposed to remote projects. Remote projects
run typechecking/linting remotely so it's less likely to encounter issues
with it.

. @ssorallen - Hmm, I think remote directories still worked, I'll have to double-check tonight though.

I think the issue is that the Node.js path module has different behaviour based on the operating system it's running on. Consequently, this means the behaviour of isValidDirectory is dependent on OS, and the spec is not taking that into account. It's checking if \a\b\c is a valid directory, which untrue on every OS. It should be checking /a/b/c on non-Windows systems, and c:\a\b\c on Windows.
I think the ideal fix is to have a test that properly handles multiple OSes:
if (on Linux) {
  runLinuxTests();
} else (on Windows) {
  runWindowsTests();
} else (on Mac OS X) {
  runMacOSXTests();
}
And then ensure the build runs on every operating system.
Alternatively, I wonder if there's a way to force Node.js to use the Win32 implementation of path.
. path.js has this at the end:
```
posix.win32 = win32.win32 = win32;
posix.posix = win32.posix = posix;
if (process.platform === 'win32')
  module.exports = win32;
else
  module.exports = posix;
```
So require('path') gets you the implementation for the current platform, and you can do require('path').win32 or require('path').posix to get a particular implementation.
I wonder if there's a way to swap out the require('path') so it explicitly requires the win32 version for unit testing (that is, what would be returned by require('path').win32). This is where a proper dependency injection framework would come in handy.
Any suggestions for what the test should do to handle this?
. @ssorallen - Just tried one approach to fix the test, let me know what you think. Rather than just overriding path.sep like it did before, I override the entire path module. This means the Windows versions of path.isAbsolute and friends are used. If you squint, it almost looks like dependency injection. :stuck_out_tongue:

guswelter:
+1
No, this happens intermittently without going to settings view. It most often happens after just starting Atom and connecting to Nuclide. If you watch (in OS X Activity Monitor) and wait for the process to go from 105% processor usage down towards 0, then Atom/Nuclide work well again. Sometimes this is a few minutes; sometimes it's a half-hour.
. This may be a duplicate of https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/199
. I built from source, and it resolved the issue completely for me. Here's what I did:
1. On client side, wipe Atom and reinstall (on OS X, be sure to  delete ~/.atom and ~/Library/Application Support/Atom before reinstall)
2. Follow Build from Source instructions at https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/README.md
3. On server side (if applicable), remove npm package: npm uninstall -g nuclide-server and then follow Build from Source instructions at https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide/server/README.md
Temporary solution until the next release.
. Running the commands that are failing manually will give you more information. For example, for the first command that's failing, do:
cd /Users/xavier/latamautos/nuclide/pkg/nuclide/source-control-helpers
sudo npm uninstall async
. Because he ran the script with sudo, and we're trying to capture the npm output as it would have occurred for the script.
. May be related to System Integrity Protection in El Capitan: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT204899
To disable: http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/208478/how-do-i-disable-system-integrity-protection-sip-aka-rootless-on-os-x-10-11
Don't forget to re-enable afterwards with csrutil enable.

sh

. @colenhuttran I'm on linux so, unfortunately, I'm unable to offer much insight on cygwin.
To check to see if it's removed, enter apm ls in the console. You'll get a list of all installed packages. If it's not in that list, you're good to go.
If it is in the list, then the bash script probably didn't work properly on your cygwin installation. This can be checked by entering just the code in the parenthaces to see if just the names of the nuclide packages are listed... (eg. apm list -b | grep -P -o "^nuclide.*(?=@)")

peterhal:
Currently the Nuclide debugger is built on the chrome dev tools UI and uses their protocol for new providers. This has worked well for getting the debugger off the ground. The chrome dev tools protocol has some JS specific aspects to its design which we are starting to bump up against. We will start building our own UI (replacing parts of the chrome UI in pieces) and extending the chrome protocol going forwards.
Would love to hear about your plans.

I'm experiencing some related issues with Atom's php-integrator-navigation that might be the cause of what the OP is referring to:

Move the input/typing cursor or "iBeam" somewhere else than what you're trying to navigate on. Put the mouse cursor on the item. Press CTRL (or the modifier key you have configured). Navigation also doesn't work when you follow up with a click.
Move the input/typing cursor or "iBeam" on the item you're trying to navigate on. Put the mouse cursor on the item. Press CTRL. The mouse cursor icon changes, but the item is not underlined. Navigation works if you follow up with a click..

. This indeed works around the issue.
1. I purged all Nuclide Atom modulesapm remove $(apm ls | awk '/nuclide-/{gsub("@.*","");print$2}'),
2. installednuclide-commonsto my home directory (cd $HOME && npm install nuclide-commons)
3. and then reinstallednuclide-installer`. 
4. I have not seen the error message since.

. Yup—happening over here too. It looks like the relative-date package used to exist on NPM, but has since been removed from the registry. Replacing the version string with "azer/relative-date" in package.json is a hacky temporary workaround. The same thing is happening with left-pad, a library by the same author.
. See https://medium.com/@azerbike/i-ve-just-liberated-my-modules-9045c06be67c#.y64upds2r
. Hi, Ben! First off, thank you for offering to support Flow type definitions in RxJS. I can't speak for Facebook (without first talking to Facebook lawyers) but I am definitely open to contributing this work over to you fine folks.
In general, we don't have a great answer yet to the question of how libraries should distribute their type definitions. We do currently have the ability to pull in type definitions from node modules—either via .js.flow files or through [includes] which fbjs does.
However, we run into issues with both of those schemes. The underlying issue is that type definitions don't always work with newer versions of Flow, or even projects on the same version that have differing configurations. The end result is that a library consumer gets Flow errors from the library code instead of their own code, which really should never happen.
We're circling a solution to this in flow-typed, which is nearly ready for everyday use. My instinct is to hold off on this until that picture becomes a bit clearer.
I should note that whatever the solution is w.r.t. pulling in 3rd party type definitions, I am still open to moving ownership of the code to RxJS. I'll make a note to follow up here in the coming weeks. Until then, let me know if there's anything else I can do to help.
.
gabelevi:
Actually strip_root was invented for the tests. We wanted to record test output in a way that was portable. If the test output included the absolute file path then they'd always need to be run from the same path. I think the tests run with --strip-root by default.
Tests that run with --json might have trouble with your solution.
I'm not sure what the value of using strip_root as a human is nowadays. The new error format will use relative paths if they're shorter.
.

. I did some more investigation and I found a fix for this problem that works for me when using the latest single package install of nuclide (version 0.115.1). It's an easy fix. See this pull request for more details: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/pull/355.

imperio59:
Same on Atom 1.19.0/Nuclide on mac OSX and a remote project folder.. This comes from a bad/wrong npm module of nuclide lingering around on the server.
I had to go the nuclear option to get this to work:
sudo apt-get remove nodejs
sudo apt-get remove npm
Then go to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ and remove any node list if you have (delete node* files). Then do a
sudo apt-get update
Then, crucial step, do 
find / -name nuclide_server_manager.py
Delete all node_modules folders that contain this file.
Then go to https://nodejs.org/en/download/package-manager/ and follow instructions to install node (I installed 8, which also installs npm)
Now normally re-install nuclide with npm install -g nuclide
And it should work.
If you get a "client version doesn't match server", remove nuclide and reinstall with npm at the right version (like npm install -g nuclide@236)..

SabeBarker:
I am having this issue on Windows 10 and Ubuntu 15.10... Was a clean install of Atom and installed nuclide-installer package.
. I have got this working without atom crashing in Windows 10 and Ubuntu 15.10:
1. I deleted all nuclide- folders in the packages folder which can be found in the .atom folder (Linux: /home/username/.atom Windows: C:\Users\username\.atom) I think that's right? I'm on my phone right now so sorry if it isn't :/
2. I installed nuclide-commons with npm install nuclide-commons
3. Installed nuclide-installer with apm install nuclide-installer
4. I then opened atom and the nuclide installer did it's thing installing other needed packages.
I'm not sure if that will help anyone but it worked for me.
.

beevelop:
@Kikobeats Yes, nuclide-commons seems not to be explicitly listed as npm dependency in nuclide-blame-provider-hg's package.json. @donald-jackson's approach worked for me too on Windows 7.
.
hackeram6:
The problem is that the ~/.atom/packages/nuclide-blame-provider-hg/package.json installs nuclide-commons in the wrong path.
"path": "node_modules/nuclide-analytics/node_modules/nuclide-commons/lib/main.js"
should have been 
  "path": "node_modules/nuclide-commons/lib/main.js"
You could move nuclide-commons to the right path. @donald-jackson's approach works as well.
.

. I am having the same symptoms. Manually starting the server starts a running process, I can telnet to 9090 and curl -X POST http://server:9090/heartbeat gives curl: (52) Empty reply from server.

Atom 1.5.3 and Nuclide 0.117.0.
. Two additional data points.
Downgrading client and server to 0.116.0, and everything seems to work fine again. I was wondering if it might be to do with the change from using an interactive shell to exec (https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/cbc5c62dfe66e73932d195edc886cb6718adefe1/pkg/nuclide/remote-connection/lib/SshHandshake.js)
In doing so, I also found a workaround (although I don't quite understand how this works).
On my laptop I run
TERM=nuclide ssh $SERVER nuclide-start-server --common-name=$SERVER --workspace=$HOME --json-output-file=/tmp/nuclide-sshhandshake-me -t 60
and then when I connect through Atom to the same server it seems to attach to the existing server process (and the two server log files show the same certificate being used).
. Thanks!

. Hey @micksabox! Nuclide actually uses your system node for this task (e.g. whichever is on $PATH). Sorry, I'll add a setting so that you can customize this. 😕
In the meantime, can you try opening Atom from the CLI in a terminal that has the right version of node on the PATH as a workaround?
. Oops! The packager doesn't actually call out to node; it just calls the packager.sh in react-native which in turn uses the node on your path.
The workaround should still do the trick, but this illustrates a need for a better $PATH story in Nuclide.
. To clarify what's going on here: Nuclide is executing the packager script in react-native which does the following:
THIS_DIR=$(dirname "$0")
node "$THIS_DIR/../local-cli/cli.js" start "$@"
So whichever node is in your $PATH is the one that's going to be used. Note, though, that Nuclide isn't going to get $PATH modifications made in your shell configurations (.bash_profile, .zshrc, etc) unless you launch it from a session that has those modifications.
There are a couple of things we could do to make this better: 1) give users more control over their $PATH within Nuclide and 2) allow alternate ways to specify the packager command. (We already have one alternative, which is a .buckconfig with a [react-native] section.)
. @Emilios1995 @micksabox With 2d735053a7140b5ee0026a18ca532d0e91f1f576, Nuclide will use the nuclide-react-native.pathToNode setting to run the packager. ("Path to Node Executable" under "Nuclide-react-native" in the Nuclide settings.) This'll be in next week's release.
Also related, once atom/atom#4126 lands, Atom should automatically pick up your PATH settings!
. Hm, this is currently the expected behavior. (If you want another directory open, you can add both to the project.)
I'm honestly not sure about recursively searching the tree for packager information. Not only is it potentially costly, it also means we'd have to account for the possibility of finding multiple RN projects. I think a better idea might be to specify the packager command in a config file in your top directory. As the error message alludes, this can already be done with a .buckconfig file that looks like this:
[react-native]
    server = path/to/node_modules/react-native/packager/packager.sh
In the future, I think we'll probably be adding other ways to configure this command (e.g. a package.json script or some kind of Nuclide-specific config) but that's still a bit up-in-the-air 😥.
EDIT: Sorry, packager.sh uses the cwd so you couldn't just call it directly like that. You'd need to create another script that uses the correct directory.

The current sorting logic sorts by type then path then line number—all either ascending or descending. Some options are:

Update the "type" sorting to be type, path, then reverse line number. This means:
type ▲ = type ascending, path ascending, line number descending
type ▼ = type descending, path descending, line number ascending
Make it so that descending sorting isn't necessarily the reverse order of ascending. Then we could always sort the lines ascending when sorting by type:
type ▲ = type ascending, path ascending, line number ascending
type ▼ = type descending, path descending, line number ascending
Add "memory" to the sorting (and more column parameters to the function) enabling you to sort by multiple columns as @ljw1004 suggests. Honestly, I'm not super thrilled with the idea because it means that the current sorting state wouldn't be indicated by the view (at least not just the arrow in the header). Also, it seems reasonable to me to expect that if you sort by type, then by line, then by type, you should be back to the original sorting whereas this wouldn't be the case.

Thoughts?

. Hey!  There are currently no written guidelines for interfacing debuggers.  I can point you to some examples that might help you -- they all have roughly the same structure.  Nuclide currently supports 3 debuggers:
1. LLDB -- works for local projects (and soon for remote projects).  Look in pkg/nuclide/debugger/lldb-{client,server}
2. HHVM -- works for remote projects only.  Look in pkg/nuclide/debugger/hhvm and pkg/nuclide/debugger-hhvm-proxy
3. Node and React Native -- works for local projects only.  Look in pkg/nuclide/debugger/node
Each of these debuggers shares common UI code in pkg/debugger/atom.  Hopefully this is enough for you to get started.  I'm going to close this issue but feel free to reopen with follow up questions, comments, etc.

. Where does it say that Hyperclick on Windows should be alt+click?  @mostafaeweda has done some work in the past to try and improve the competition between multiple cursors and Hyperclick.  The current behavior is:
When there are Hyperclick results ready, it's assumed you want to use Hyperclick instead of using the multi-cursor feature -- so, the event is prevented from propagating up triggering the multi-cursor feature.
However, when the Hyperclick has no results, e.g. clicking at the end of the line, or on non-symbols we delegate to the multi-cursor feature.
We don't want to change away from ctrl/cmd+click for Hyperclick because it's a keybinding that a lot of editors choose.  One solution is to make it clearer when Hyperclick has given up or is otherwise not doing "Hyperclick" work, and has delegated to the multi-cursor functionality.

Closing this as duplicate.. Hi everybody, I have a fix in review for this.  I'm going to explain what the issue was:
Currently Nuclide's RN debugger works by requesting JS from the packager, executing that JS in a Node process, and then debugging that process.  This strategy works pretty well but sometimes can be problematic.  The reason is that Node (and therefore Nuclide's debugger) uses V8 to execute JS code, whereas devices and simulators use a different JS runtime called JavaScriptCore (JSC).  The root cause of this issue turned out to be a discrepancy between how JSC and V8 handle the delete keyword.  This line was the culprit:
https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/master/Libraries/Core/InitializeCore.js#L160
This delete failed in a V8 context, and succeeded in a JSC context.  The expectation is that this property is a getter which is deleted after its first use, and replaced with the actual value inside the require.  Since the delete failed, the getter was never replaced, and ended up being called recursively, until a stack overflow occurred.
Because having the debug environment be different from the production environment is so hazardous, we're going to revamp the RN debugger so that it actually debugs code running inside JSC.  This will eliminate this class of (terrible) bugs, and give a more reliable and stable debugging experience.  Thank you for bearing with us!
Big thank you to @matthewwithanm for gently pushing me to get a fix out for this!

thetrompf:
I have managed to get the flow type checker up and running on windows.
I stumbled upon two issues when trying to get to work on Windows. First of all the way nuclide is trying to locate the binary even when specifying absolute path, is essentially running which flow or if the absolute path is filled out which c:\some\path\to\flow.exe. The problem here is that windows doesn't have the which command. I borrowed it from the git mingw binaries. I copied which.exe and msys-2.0.dll to c:\unix-utils and added c:\unix-utils to PATH. The second problem is that Windows is case-insensitive when using environment variables. And I have added the my unix-utils path to the already existing Path environment variable. But when nuclide access' the environment variable it does it by process.env.PATH which unfortunately was not where I added the path.
So lastly I renamed the Path variables (both system-wide and local) to PATH, now I just restarted atom and it worked.
Note: I have downloaded the pre-compiled windows binaries and extracted it to c:\flowtype and added that to PATH as well.
Note: My Git for windows is faily new, and I found the unix-util binaries at C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin on my x64 windows 10 machine.

ZebraFlesh:
I did uninstall it from the Atom UI. I'd expect an uninstalled to completely reverse its actions. 
. If a package can't tell when it's being uninstalled, then perhaps the right answer is for nuclide to only be additive: the original tree-view package should be left intact and the nuclide tree should be shown beside it. In the event of an error (such as installing on windows :scream: ), Atom's base functionality is left intact.
. @ssorallen ^^^ And that's the problem by optimizing for the wrong thing. Ask anyone who has written installation software before and one of the top rules is "do no harm" followed by "clean up after yourself". Unfortunately, nuclide is doing neither on Windows right now. And since it's the only mercurial integration for atom, you're going to continue to see this issue grow until Windows support is landed (#331).
. Windows isn't supported yet: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/321
.

standa:
I got it working by physically removing every directory with nuclide_server_manager.py. In my case for some reason there were three versions of nuclide_server_manager.py in $HOME/.npm/nuclide, /usr/local/ and some other /usr/lib. Now I only have this one: /usr/lib/node_modules/nuclide/pkg/nuclide/server/scripts/nuclide_server_manager.py
Try:
- locate nuclide_server_manager.py
- npm remove -g nuclide
- rm -R $DIRS_WITH_nuclide_server_manager_py
- npm install -g nuclide
.

jordwalke:
I'll be hopefully adding more and more features for OCaml development into Nuclide. I'll be targeting a new unreleased version of Merlin though which is why I must tap into the lower level protocol.
. How would I do this such that it works remotely as well?
. I'm still learning about Nuclide. Why can't local services just be remote services that happen to point to localhost. Seems like that architecture would make developing for Nuclide much easier.
. I wish there was a way to develop without having to worry about testing in two modes. Why not just have a way to go through the serialization path even when developing locally? This lowers the barrier to contributing.
. Yes, that would go a long ways. There are people (such as myself the first time I looked into contributing), who try contributing and then before submitting the pull request, they back out because there's this completely other mode which they don't understand.
. I updated this PR so that the arguments are future-proof serializable in the event that some serializable automation is added. It doesn't look like it matters because this is not serialized IIRC.
. Does this look good to go?
. Yeah awesome thanks.
. I think we've got an even better solution coming up! :D
. I can swap it out if you like - especially if there's precedence for using this utility. I don't care either way, because there are so few arguments that are typically passed to ocamlmerlin at startup time.
. I looked into that library and its probably overkill for merlin's use case (since in practice there's only one/two command line flag that you'd actually use and the rest should appear project scoped to a .merlin library).
I'm happy to add it if you feel strongly.
. These four lines should probably be a little utility function since it occurs twice.
. Is there a cross platform way to join paths? I genuinely do not know.
.

It seems we don't have any lint protection against this yet :(. Yes! Here's a detailed rundown of what happens with the default configuration:
1) We establish an SSH connection to your remote server and then execute nuclide-start-server (or whatever you type into the Remote Connection dialog). [1]
2) nuclide-start-server then starts up nuclide_server_manager.py, which randomly generates a HTTPS certificate, signing authority and client key. Unless you pass --insecure, of course.
3) The Nuclide server uses these certificates to start an HTTPS WebSocket server. The cert/CA/key is then passed back over the SSH connection and stored in the Atom client, and also encrypted and saved in the OS keychain for easy reconnection.
4) Finally, client side, the NuclideSocket class uses these credentials to establish the HTTPS WebSocket connection. All client-server Nuclide interactions go through this connection..
