We've received reports of an issue where pacman incorrectly installs the wrong Electron version as a dependency, leading to a similar error for Nuclide's terminal: https://github.com/facebook-atom/atom-ide-ui/issues/241#issuecomment-388630859
You can install Atom from the tarball in https://atom.io/releases as a workaround.. Atom 1.26.1 is using Electron 1.7.11. (Electron 2.0.0 has landed in Atom master and will likely be released in 1.28, though.). No easy fixes here, unfortunately! We'd welcome a community contribution here; the code that gets Python diagnostics is over here: https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide-python-rpc/lib/PythonService.js#L457
Since this is running on the server, the config would have to be read and sent up from the caller of this function (over in pkg/nuclide-python).. Seems like you've set your system Python version to 3, which APM doesn't really like (looks like it dies while trying to install "fsevents" which has some native dependencies.) Is it possible to revert the system Python version to 2?
Otherwise you could stick to v0.301.0 of Nuclide, which doesn't have the "fsevents" dependency (which is included transitively by the "jest" dependency). cc @aaronabramov @captbaritone - looks like 'jest' includes some native dependencies, which can cause some unpleasant behavior.. Yeah I think the workaround is to rollback to v0.301.0 for now. (I don't know how to resolve the underlying 'msbuild' issue here, but we'll probably remove "jest" from the dependencies for the next release.). Makes sense! Re the original issue: do you mind also adding this to nuclide-flow? Flow is actually the main provider of autocomplete suggestions for JS files in Nuclide.
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide-flow/lib/main.js#L147. Perfect. Thanks for your contribution!. see #1541 - you'll need to downgrade to v303 for now.. Ah yeah we switched to passing the port option in as part of a JSON blob.
You can still use the --port=8080 flag but it has to be through the Nuclide UI:

We'll silently parse that flag out and put it into the JSON blob for you.. cc @semmypurewal - people are already using Nuclide with Docker :). I don't think there's any PHP / TypeScript integration for Nuclide at the moment, unfortunately. If you use HHVM/Hack, Nuclide should support your project, though.
We may be able to support configuring arbitrary remote LSP servers in the near future!. Thanks, just needs the CLA!. Ctrl+Shift+P isn't something that Nuclide provides - that's https://github.com/atom/command-palette.. Simplify the boolean expression! :P
!A || A && B === !A || B
. what do you mean? the second "selectionRangeEmpty" check is redundant, so it actually avoids an extra check - to clarify, what I mean is
if (provider.formatCode != null && (!selectionRangeEmpty || provider.formatEntireFile == null))) {
IMO it's just as readable - the explanation would be "use me if the range is non-empty, or we're forced to because formatEntireFile isn't defined."
. Make sure you document the flag exclusion as well.
I would also specifically state that the additional flags are to be added after the ones in compile_commands.json.. This is a bit heavyhanded - just leave these as Array<string> in this state.. We only have one ClangFlagsManager for each remote server, so you need to also disambiguate by project. Also note that you need to cache the actual Promise, as otherwise this creates a race condition when multiple files are opened simultaneously. This should probably be a Map<string, Promise<?ClangProjectFlags>>. Nitpick: I would prefer writing this snippet as
if (projectFlagsDir == null) {
  return originalFlags;
}
const projectFlagsFile = ...
const projectFlags = await this._....
if (projectFlags == null) {
  return originalFlags;
}
to avoid mutation & make the intent clearer. Nitpick: the slice is unnecessary. we can write this block in the functional style:
return originalFlags
  .filter(flag => ignoredCompilerFlags.indexOf(flag) === -1)
  .concat(extraCompilerFlags);. After changing these to plain arrays the || [] should be unnecessary. As mentioned above, I'd just leave these as the raw arrays.
Also it's probably a good idea to make these fields optional in the config, so make sure you handle the case where they're null.. As mentioned above, you need to look this up by flagsFile. And you need to cache the promise- see the getFlagsForSrc cached vs impl pattern above. Let's use a real temporary directory for this test. We have a copyFixture utility (see https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/648d770f3f58794dbdcfa1b0d9ccf6ae484e1581/spec/clang-refactor-integration-spec.js#L25), so let's copy out the fixtures directory. The temporary directory will be automatically cleaned up so no need for the manual afterEach either :). The Atom code always keeps this non-null/non-empty (and we've Flow-typed it as such), so I think that's fine to assume here as well. Let's just inline options as {encoding} below.. Nuclide uses a transform to lazy-require all imports, so just import this at the top of the file in the usual way.. Something about this feels off. Does this work? Doesn't this implicitly encode the buffer as a UTF-8 string? Or does this work because the readFile call implicitly decodes into a UTF-8 string?
Is that guaranteed to work? IMO it would be clearer and more preferable to keep the readFile call encoding-agnostic, let it keep returning a raw Buffer, and do the decoding here (as with Atom's implementation).. ditto. We've taken to using prettier to format our code so you gotta remove these spaces. It looks like this should be moved to rpc-types.js so you can actually use it from both OutlineTreeForUi and OutlineTree. Or is there something blocking that?. Can you actually make this kind?: OutlineTreeKind now? (Same above).. Ohh yeah.. unfortunately we don't have great docs about this :( atom$Octicon is not supported because that's a type from flow-libs, which the RPC framework doesn't know about. Rest assured that simple literal unions like this one should work fine.
There's an option in Nuclide settings called "Use local RPC" that is sufficient for testing this (just make sure Flow outlines still work, for example)..

micksabox:
@matthewwithanm opening Atom from the CLI did not work as well. Luckily, you put me on the right track and I realized I had another version of node installed in my $PATH. Once removed, the packager worked as expected.
. @cco5566  what I ended up doing was symlinked the latest nvm version of node (mine is v5.0.0) to the path /usr/bin/node (If there was a node install there already I removed it). I think that Nuclide looks for the node installed specifically at /usr/bin/node, so just by symlinking it to the right version this solved the problem.
. @Emilios1995 As per my answer above, I removed the existing node binary in /usr/bin/ and made a new file called node there, and symlinked it to the v5.0.0 version of node. I followed instructions here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1951742/how-to-symlink-a-file-in-linux. Basically, symlink is like a file redirect, so whenever something is looking for the node in /usr/bin, it will get redirected to the v5.0.0 version. Good luck.
. Gotcha, thanks. I agree with you. Although the error message makes it seem like this is possible, which is why I opened this issue. I'll close it for now.

. Great idea! I believe @jgebhardt is working with you on this so I'll just chime in with a few thoughts :)
I think a good specific use case would be integration with the very new and already quite popular "Create React App": https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app
This is an example where the project files are dynamically created. So it's a good example of where static template formats will not work with a potentially important use case. React Native's cli (e.g. react-native init for new RN projects) is another example.
My perspective is that you can support both static template and dynamically-generated projects by structuring the new project wizard to be pluggable. So you have different providers for the different types of new file/project wizards, e.g. one for "Create React App" and one for a static template format. 
And the design of the API that supports the pluggability is informed by exploring both types of wizards. You could start off by looking at creating a provider for "Create React App", since that's already a proven/working system. And then for bonus points, explore a provider for the static template format (e.g. new React component files, new Xcode projects, etc). That could help ensure you are supporting a broad set of "new wizard" use cases.

deeprest:
workaround for Debian, with llvm-3.8 and python2.7:
 Atom: 1.20.0
 Nuclide: 0.252.0
* Client OS: Debian 9 (stretch)
Partially taken from bottledwalter's SO link above:
PYTHON=2.7
LLVM=3.8
LLVM_PATCH=1
pushd /usr/lib/llvm-$LLVM/lib/python$PYTHON/site-packages/lldb
sudo rm _lldb.so libLLVM-$LLVM.0.so.1 libLLVM-$LLVM.so.1
sudo ln -s ../../../liblldb.so.1 _lldb.so
sudo ln -s ../../../libLLVM-$LLVM.$LLVM_PATCH.so.1 libLLVM-$LLVM.0.so.1
sudo ln -s ../../../libLLVM-$LLVM.$LLVM_PATCH.so.1 libLLVM-$LLVM.so.1
popd
This was necessary for the Atom.io Nuclide debugger to find module _lldb
sudo ln -s /usr/lib/llvm-$LLVM/lib/liblldb.so /usr/lib/python$PYTHON/dist-packages/_lldb.so
Check that python can import lldb without exporting the path first
python
>>> import lldb
If that works then hopefully the Nuclide debugger works too

Huh, I could have sworn that I was completely unable to get it working a couple of days ago, but trying it again today I am successful; I now see visible, grayed out entries for .git and files in .gitignore in the Nuclide file tree.  Here is a messy project in the middle of migration:

Here's my config.cson for other lost souls to compare against.
An aside: Playing around with the settings, I observe that the two configuration options discussed above each have the effect of hiding files (in the sense of being removed entirely from the file list), but by two completely orthogonal criteria:
- Setting core["excludeVcsIgnoredPaths"] hides exactly those files which are grayed-out. (.git plus those in .gitignore)
- Setting nuclide["nuclide-file-tree"]["hideIgnoredNames"] hides exactly those files which match core["ignoredNames"]. (in this image, those are .git and src/.draw.ts.swp)
It is nice that these work orthogonally to each other, as I find the second option desirable.

frogcjn:
I think the problem is that if there is no error, then the parameter value is empty, then JSON.parse('') will report an error.
. @nmote
Its source is result = await this._process.execFlow(args, options, file, /* waitForServer */ true); in FlowRoot.js
"Async Execution Error"
Fatal error: exception End_of_file
. Should it be https://github.com/facebook/flow/issues/937  ?
It seems that flow server is not running correctly:
flow status => Fatal error: exception End_of_file
So if flow in this status, then result.stdout will be empty. In this case, we should avoid to parse it.

freebroccolo:
What about using a different comment pattern for these cases? Maybe something like this:
javascript
// $FlowFBRequire
gatekeeper = require('../fb-gatekeeper').gatekeeper;
If you used a special comment pattern, you could either swap out the .flowconfig file or edit it with sed (the .flowconfig file) or something like that for the internal case where you don't want flow to ignore it.
. Having to maintain a separate file internally would be a hassle, I agree. I'm thinking maybe you would have to go that far though. Is there some way to conditionally set certain directives in the .flowconfig file from the flow command or anything like that?
Even if there isn't, if a special comment pattern like $FlowFBRequire were used here instead of $FlowIgnore, you could add a line to the .flowconfig file like this:
``` editorconfig
[options]
suppress_comment=.\$FlowFixMe.
suppress_comment=.\$FlowIssue.
suppress_comment=.\$FlowIgnore.
suppress_comment=.\$FlowFBRequire.
```
That way external users would have an easy way to ignore these errors without causing any trouble in the default case for internal users. You could then either just mention that this line should be uncommented for external users in the documentation or you could provide an option to one of the scripts which would do it automatically.
. I've implemented this last suggestion. I think this approach shouldn't cause any problems for internal users and it's easy enough for me to just uncomment the one line in .flowconfig.

wez:
Please share the output from watchman watch-list, or if it won't let you run that, please share the contents of your state file; it can be found alongside the log file.  See https://facebook.github.io/watchman/docs/troubleshooting.html#where-are-the-logs for information on how to locate that on your system.
. Yep, take a look at these configuration options:
https://facebook.github.io/watchman/docs/config.html#root_files
https://facebook.github.io/watchman/docs/config.html#enforce_root_files
You can enable the default mode for this by creating the file /etc/watchman.json with these contents:
{"enforce_root_files": true}
This will cause watchman to only allow watching dirs that have a git or mercurial repo at their root, or that have a .watchmanconfig file at the root.  You can customize the root_files list to match whatever criteria make the most sense for your usage.
For this to take effect, especially as you are hitting system limits, you should run:
pkill watchman
rm /path/to/$USER-state/state
to ensure that all outstanding watches are cancelled (we'd normally just run watchman watch-del-all, but this won't function correctly while watchman is in a poisoned state).
Each time you change /etc/watchman.json, you will need to run watchman shutdown-server in order for those changes to take effect.

koba04:
Thank you!

Unfortunately, this is a glaring security vulnerability since Nuclide runs Flow all the time while you are browsing. So, just by downloading and browsing a malicious project, your machine will get completely owned. They could just have a repository with their code in node_modules/bin/flow or whatever the path is, and bam.

I understand what you are concerned about.
I'd like to use flow with flow-bin installed as a devDependencies because of being dependencies explicitly.
I like the following style:
- npm install
- npm start
- start development
But I understand a security issue for Nuclide supports this style.
It's a very difficult problem.
Also, I think some other editor plugins(ESLint etc..) have the same issue.

Distribute something like our internal wrapper script

👍  for this. It would be nice that the script is able to install(uninstall) flow easily.
We generally use different versions of languages and libraries by each projects.
So I think any solutions for supporting multiple flow versions which don't depend on Nuclide are important.
.
satya164:
Thanks for the write up.

I'd be willing to implement a setting to enable this (with a scary description so people know the risk they are taking on), if there is demand, but that only works for people who know to ask for it. It would be better to fix this issue for everyone.

This is already how other plugins like ESLint work. So I think it should be fine to expect people to enable this explicitly.
Another solution is to show a banner before starting flow, and the user can enable flow from node_modules for that project knowingly.

Distribute something like our internal wrapper script

That sounds interesting. How does installing multiple flow versions work with the wrapper?

Bundle Flow with Nuclide

How will this work? Will Nuclide has to bundle every flow version available? 
. > the deps it needs to download flow are larger than the flow bins themselves
sounds like bundling the binaries will be much better :)
I usually use a local npm caching tool like npm_lazy due to the long npm install times, and since flow-bin always downloads the binary, I can't use the cache for it.

mrienstra:
Related: the current documentation regarding this topic is a little confusing.
E.g.
https://nuclide.io/docs/languages/flow/#installing-flow
doesn't explicitly discuss installing Flow globally, and links to
https://flow.org/en/docs/getting-started/#installing-flow
(should be https://flow.org/en/docs/install/ )
which says "Flow works best when installed per-project with explicit versioning rather than globally."
https://github.com/facebook/flow#installing-flow
also discourages global use.
As it is, it's easy for new users to end up going in circles for a bit.
At the very least maybe something should be added to https://nuclide.io/docs/help/troubleshooting/#flow-issues ?.

@matthewwithanm I thought of a few alternatives:
1. Disable/gray-out the task runner toolbar when the project root is set to a path that doesn't contain a Package.swift file. 
2. Update based on the current project root no matter what. Instead of attempting to guess what is and isn't a Swift package, we allow the task runner toolbar to attempt to build/test anyway.
I don't mind the current "sticky" behavior, but if either of the above is more common in Nuclide, I'll implement that.

. That's strange. The error message you're seeing is coming from the Swift compiler. I would certainly expect this error message to be the same regardless of whether you invoke sourcekitten via the command line, or via Nuclide.
The nuclide-swift packages passes an additional set of compiler flags to SourceKitten here. It looks like those flags may be causing the Swift compiler to produce that error. That's strange, since the commands should be the exact ones included in the YAML file SwiftPM produces.
The best way to diagnose the issue would be to add a console.log to your Nuclide installation on the line that I linked to above. Take a look at the compiler arguments being passed to SourceKitten. If you invoke SourceKitten yourself with those same arguments, does it produce an error? If so, check the YAML file SwiftPM produces (I believe it's called debug.yaml or release.yaml. Do the compiler arguments in that file work? If not, perhaps this is an issue with SwiftPM.
. > Issue was related with libraries of sourcekit.
So it was an issue with SourceKit and SourceKitten? Is there an issue on the SourceKitten repository, or a Swift JIRA bug report that explains what the issue was? I'm curious to see if I can help. :)
. Thanks for the detailed report! It sounds like SourceKitten on Linux requires some additional environment variables to be set. Perhaps the best way forward is to provide Nuclide configuration options for those paths, so that users may set them to the correct paths and get SourceKitten working.

eliseumds:
That would be a great improvement. When firing up flow from the terminal, you'll see the path to a log file. Tail that file (tail -f PATH_HERE) and check whether it is running out of memory. If so, it probably means you have to ignore directories in your .flowconfig. By default, it will look for every single file inside the project root, so be very careful. Here's my current config (Flow 0.54.0):
```
[include]
[ignore]
./.git/.
/.happypack/.
/node_modules/.
[libs]
[options]
module.system.node.resolve_dirname=node_modules
Module aliasing (NODE_PATH)
module.system.node.resolve_dirname=src/clients
suppress_comment=\(.\|\n\)*\$FlowFixMe
esproposal.class_instance_fields=enable
esproposal.class_static_fields=enable
webpack loaders
module.name_mapper='..s?css$' -> '/flow/styles-loader.js'
module.name_mapper='..(svg\|png\|jpg\|gif)$' -> '/flow/url-loader.js'
```.

Ok, I understand and I know other editors use the familiar ctrl+click. Don't want to interfere with previous work. But the README confused me, as it states:

Hyperclick is triggered by two events:
- <alt> or <alt-mousemove> underlines clickable text under the mouse.
- <alt-mousedown> performs the action associated with the clickable text.
- <cmd-alt-enter> performs the action on the text under the cursor.

So I thought the alt-key was the preferred key. I often use the multi-selection/cursor feature in Atom to select items which do have Hyperclick results. I need to disable the Hyperclick package to do that.

- There is a text selection active;

junpengxiao:
I recently met a similar issue when setting nuclide server. nuclide-start-server cannot be found. If I use the full path, then the log shows node cannot be found.
I am not sure if this is because I have both .profile and .bashrc. It seems environment path isn't exported correctly.
If someone met the same issue as I did, it is better to just add brew path into system environment.
```
sudo emacs /etc/environment
Add brew bin (the default one is /home/username/.linuxbrew/bin) into the PATH variable
sudo reboot
```
This will solve the issue.

a2xchip:
Absolute path to nuclide-server will not help cause then you will got something like no such command nohup node it causes because of using non-standard path variables and non-interactive mode
To test variables path in non-interactive mod fast use:
```
ssh remote.server 'bash -l -c "node"'
or
ssh remote.server 'bash -l -c "nuclide-start-server"'
```
my errors was caused by nvm node & npm installation all i did is relocated ~/.bashrc includes of nvm putting them before script exit
```
export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && . "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" # This loads nvm
script exits after lines below if mode noninteractive
[ -z "$PS1" ] && return
```
or 
```
export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && . "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" # This loads nvm
If not running interactively, don't do anything
case $- in
    i) ;;
      *) return;;
esac
```
other files like ~/.bash_profile are not sourced during non-interactive mode
.
theFuzzyWebDev:
I know this is an old post but thank you a2xchip, your last post led me to fix an issue I was having the past few days!. I think I've solved my issue!
I am now able to get Nuclide connected to my server again.
In the process I ended up doing away with Putty/Pageant and moving to Git Bash/ssh-agent, Issue #625 pointed me in the right direction.
I finally edited my .bashrc as well with:
```
export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm"
[ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && . "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" # This loads nvm
script exits after lines below if mode noninteractive
[ -z "$PS1" ] && return
```
I'd had both blocks in there to begin with but the NVM block was added to the bottom by default on install and the 'script exits' block has been at the beginning. Moving the NVM block above it was the final key piece it seems.

billschaller:
Gah, this is a dupe of https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/issues/619 but I think the additional info might be helpful...
. @shushz ^
. Can confirm - fixed in latest.
. Also: I did some measurement - on a >32-core machine
| max_workers | seconds elapsed for flow check |
| --- | --- |
| 4 | 365 |
| 8 | 197 |
| 16 | 131 |
| 32 | 119 |
. Yes, running flow with nice would be nice. I did not test that specifically, but right now it's running at the default nice value of 0. 
Even with nice though, "Use all but 2 cores" is pretty extreme. If you graph the dropoff in runtime gains, you see that amdahl's law kicks in pretty quick on pretty much any feasible system, even with enterprise SSDs. Something more conservative like x/2 or x^(.66) would be a better default than what it's doing now.

. @modocache Yep, it is working!
Performance/Accuracy
So far it seems very accurate. Performance is fine overall; there seem to be some freezes here and there but I can’t reliably determine a pattern that triggers them.
Autocompletion
It’s super cool that there’s autocompletion for infix operators! The inlining of documentation in the suggestions is working well, too.
One of the biggest “issues” right now is the lack of autocompletion that would show all members of an instance as soon as the “.” is typed. E.g. having suggestions when typing self. would be very useful. I’m not sure if that’s only happening for my project or if that’s a known limitation as of know. As soon as I type an additional character (e.g. self.s) the suggestions work great.
Snippets/Tabs
Regarding snippets: I’m assuming you are referring to the standard Atom/Nuclide feature? I’ve only used Atom a tiny bit and haven’t used Nuclide before so I haven’t used the snippets features yet.
Regarding tabs: are you referring to formatting or support for working in multiple tabs?

. This started with Atom release: https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.17.0
This is what we are seeing:

It opens on top of which ever pane you have currently focused. I think it is just a css issue due to renamed or restructured classes.
When selecting a file it closes, so maybe this is meant to be a new modal dialog; but it isn't working right at all.
Thanks !. Actually I'm getting the same behavior with nuclide disabled. It happens if I split the pane.. I would guess this has to do with the new docks feature: http://blog.atom.io/2017/05/16/atom-1-17.html
It's good that there is an official API for sidebars and panels.. Oh. Very non-obvious. Glad you figured it out, thanks !
You can also drag the diagnostics down to the bottom pane.. Sorry, this is still really unusable.  You can drag the file tree into a sidebar, but the next time you open the project it is back to the main. Double click a file in the file tree and it opens in the SAME pane as the file tree.

. Install nuclide.
I will post other packages that are installed but I don't know what could possibly cause this other than nuclide tree view itself.
Split panes ? Off the top of my head that is core atom.. It might have been this https://atom.io/packages/pane-layout-plus that caused it.
Though it looks like it is just calling atom core pane API: https://github.com/chemoish/atom-pane-layout/blob/master/lib/pane-layout-formatter.coffee
I've disabled it and it seems fine for now.
This is what I've seen:

It affects all nuclide panels (File Tree, Diagnostics, Outline View)
. You now have to drag the file tree into the sidebar. Drag it from the filename tab "File Tree" into the left edge. Look for the <  icon to appear. 
Same with diagnostics panel. But they aren't stable there, they will reappear in main when you reopen the project. Sometimes files are opened in the panel rather than the main area.  Doesn't work with splits very well.. Disabling nuclide and then re-enabling managed to clear them out. It was a serious performance drag..

. Found the cause!
I have strip_root=true in my flow config under [options], removing it fixes it.
``` diff
[options]
module.name_mapper='.(.css)' -> 'CSSModule'
module.name_mapper='.(.scss)' -> 'CSSModule'
- strip_root=true
[libs]
[...]
```
.

. Did more tests yesterday. Found location where sourcekitten works properly. Issue was related with  libraries of sourcekit.
Autocompletion doesn't appear correctly for instance methods:
let a = []
a.  doesn't appear
a.a  appear
Kind source.lang.swift.decl.function.method.instance exists in sourcekitten's result. It's stdout logged by atom's dev console when I tried to complete a.
. As you could understand sourcekit, sourcekitten were builded using docker, link. Norio Nomura has implemented custom build for sourcekit (link) in on linux, which not contains in main swift repo.
In the end we have only builded sourcekitten, some of dependencies were in docker containers. So I needed to solve problems with some of it:
- error while loading shared libraries: libswiftCore.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
  It was solved by additional library path in .bashrc: export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$SWIFTENV_ROOT/versions/3.0.1-RELEASE/usr/lib/swift/linux:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH" (i'm using swiftenv, $SWIFTENV_ROOT located in ~/,switenv
- <unknown>:0: error: unable to load standard library for target 'x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu'
  I didn't find exact reason. But I think this error related with dynamic linking for stdlib. Probably in my case missed dependency in libsourcekitdInProc.so or libswiftCore.so (link, link)
  Solved by adding in .bashrc:
  export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="/usr/include:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH"
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH"
export LINUX_SOURCEKIT_LIB_PATH="$SWIFTENV_ROOT/versions/3.0.1-RELEASE/usr/lib/libsourcekitdInProc.so"
  Also sourcekitten should be located near libsourcekitdInProc.so, in swift/usr/lib/. Now my current path to soucekitten is ~/swftenv/versions/3.0.1-RELEASE/usr/lib/sourcekitten. I don't know why but it works only here althought I added LINUX_SOURCEKIT_LIB_PATH env var and tried to move sourcekitten to /opt/sourcekitten/. Anyway I added link of sourcekitten to /ust/bin.
To use sourcekitten I needed launch atom using terminal (sourcekitten should use env vars for normal work).
It's all. You can correct me, some of this stuff I did first time or long time ago.
By the way, have you any plans to support swift modules or multiple files? For example I see we can't use completion in this case: use public/internal stuff from A.swift in B.swift. If yes how soon?

This will be fixed with the next release of Nuclide (0.241). I just started hacking around this, i'll hopefully have it up and running soon. Will update once it gets going :). I am extremely sorry for the lack of responses and updates here, this is unfortunately not on our roadmap, I did try to put in some effort into this but was unable to prioritize this. . I am extremely sorry about closing this without leaving an explanation.
The diff view is an fb internal only feature that at one point used to be open sourced. We had to do this because of how many fb specific features we were adding to it and over time the diff view wasn't providing enough value to external contributors and users. Unfortunately we weren't able to gate the context menu options to only show up in the internal build and this is one of those occurrences where the reference to diff view is externally shown. I'm sad to say this but the feature won't be open sourced :( .

. It has been disappointing to see version control integration in the release notes that I can't use. 😞 Especially considering we are moving from PhpStorm which has state of the art Git integration.. Also broken when function occurs in a type parameter to a generic interface method:

Removing the type parameter on the method fixes it. For some reason generic methods (but not functions) get different colors for their name than non-generic ones, which is possibly related.
I defined these types to work around it (the problem also occurs in the definition of these types, even with GitHub's syntax highlighter):
hack
type fun0<+T> = (function(): T);
type fun1<-T1, +T> = (function(T1): T);
type fun2<-T1, -T2, +T> = (function(T1, T2): T);
type fun3<-T1, -T2, -T3, +T> = (function(T1, T2, T3): T);
It was bugs like this that led me to consider using token_get_all() to create a syntax highlighter in PHP/Hack to test Nuclide's highlighter against.
. I can't think of any programming languages that are regular languages, since a regular language wouldn't be able to have nested parenthesis.
Atom's language grammars (based on TextMate) allow recursive rules which means it can parse non-regular languages. Vim's syntax definitions are similar. It'd be pretty useless otherwise.
. The brokenness I mentioned above with function parameters was recently fixed (probably by https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/commit/2c7e6aedbaadce16e1f2950224370d8a565113e3 ?) but the original issue with (function in a shape still stands.
. What's the relationship with the tool-bar package? It wasn't installed by default by installing nuclide.
Installing the tool-bar package manually doesn't help. Restarting Atom doesn't help. Reinstalling and deleting ~/.atom and starting from scratch also didn't help.
. @leeahoward @shushz That fixed it. My home dir is a Git repo with a .gitignore that ignores everything (link), and my project repo is directly inside my home dir, so Atom hides it because it is hidden by the repo it is inside of. That's definitely a bug - a project root should never be hidden.
Moving the project one level deeper fixes it, but I'm not sure why, since it's still effectively ignored by the outer repo. Probably just a quirk of how Atom handles .gitignores.. This was in the log file:
[2016-10-27T18:52:58.651Z] [ERROR] nuclide-debugger-php - Exception handling command 26: Error: xdebug ports are equal in attach mode Error: xdebug ports are equal in attach mode

Changing the launch port from 9000 back to 10112 (the default) fixes it. Debugging still doesn't work, but it's at least listening for connections now. (I changed the launch port from the default to 9000 in an attempt to fix debugging, without realising I had just broken it further.)
It would have been nice if that Error: xdebug ports are equal in attach mode message appeared in the UI.

The issue seemed to be tied to the fact that I relocated my brew installation away from the default location and into my home directory. However, when I moved the installation, there was still a ton of stuff left over in /usr/local/ that had to be wiped out as it was causing a lot of problems.
After wiping out pretty much everything in there that didn't need to be in there, deleting ~/.atom and ~/Library/Preferences/com.github.atom.plist, properly reinstalling everything (mercurial, python, atom, etc), and rebooting, the issue cleared up.

. Seems like I was running an old version of mercurial. Upgrading to the latest version (v4.0) solved this issue for me. You can check your mercurial version using:
hg version
I tried reinstalling mercurial using:
sudo apt-get install mercurial
which told me that I already had the latest version. Apparently to get the latest version you need to install it via pip:
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:mercurial-ppa/releases
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y mercurial
.
SRandazzo:
@Maxwell2022 I had the same issue after upgrading.
I closed atom and deleted ~/.atom/storage, emptied trash and relaunched atom.
My issue is now solved
Hope this helps you or anyone else!

jmorrell:
Hmm... I was unaware undocumented APIs were considered private. I, perhaps naively, assumed that the public documentation was lacking and went straight to the code. 
- Does this come from the Atom team or the Nuclide team?
- While it makes sense to avoid using undocumented methods, I'm not sure leaving them untyped provides any great benefit? Perhaps that only makes sense once it's under flow-typed and can be pegged against atom's version

. I was able to rewrite my module using only the documented APIs / existing flow annotations so I'm going to close this PR. Thanks for the review and guidance!

AlexTalks:
This issue has been bothering me as well somewhat.  YCM has the concept of the .ycm_extra_conf.py for manually providing additional compilation flags for libclang, so I figured a similar solution could be useful here.  I've added support for reading a nuclide_clang_flags.json, which allows manually specifying project-wide compiler flags to add, flags to filter out, and -isystem paths to include.  This solution seems to be working pretty well for me thus far actually.
If it sounds useful I'm happy to submit it as a pull request.. @hansonw I figure you're the right person to notify about this?. @hansonw sure!  sounds reasonable about moving to a standard .nucliderc at some point.
As for the naming, I tried to follow conventions set by Buck and Bazel, though Buck doesn't have the nocopts feature so I stuck with Bazel's naming.  In keeping more in line with Buck's naming however, I could just use { "compiler_flags": [..], "exclude_compiler_flags": [..] } if that makes more sense.. @hansonw thanks for the feedback!  will fix up your comments and push another commit.. @hansonw added the commit.  I'm not sure if @facebook-github-bot expects us to have amended our earlier commits, or have pushed a new commit?  (Also I somewhat assume that arcanist actually squashes the PR before merge or something). @janosimas an easy way to check it to see the running instances of clang_server.py and see what flags it is using for each translation unit.  For me I needed to make sure that the actual paths of the system header files were passed in through -isystem include flags.. good to know.  I didn't realize how that worked, but of course that makes sense..

Alhadis:
I better weigh in on this...
Hi guys, I help maintain the File-Icons repository. I'm solely responsible for the mess I unknowingly thrust onto Nuclide's users, because I only just learned of its existence in the last 24 hours.
The reason your users are suddenly seeing this in their workspace is because the nuclide-file-tree isn't consuming Atom's icon service the way the built-in tree-view does:
json
"consumedServices": {
    "atom.file-icons": {
        "versions": {
            "1.0.0": "consumeFileIcons"
        }
    }
}
Now, before somebody rushes off to apply a hasty hotfix, I better explain the other half of the issue: Atom's icon service is too limited to be of use to File-Icons. I had to monkey-patch five core packages with absurd gymnastics and Promise-riddled hackery to get icons updating correctly. This was necessitated by the Atom team's decision to keep the service "simple": that is, barring packages any DOM access whatsoever.
Now, Atom's package code is easy to hack. Obviously, yours is not. I tried jackhammering Nuclide into cooperation with a MutationObserver to update element classes, which... uh... didn't go too well.
To TL;DR this for you: I'm in the final stages of developing our own icon service, which will obviate gorilla-punching the crap out of package classes at runtime. I urge you to use this first, Atom's API second. Here's how I did it when testing it locally with a fork of tree-view:
```coffee
    if service = IconServices.get 'element-icons'
      service.addIconToElement @fileName,
        path: @file.path
        type: 'file'
    else
      service = IconServices.get 'file-icons'
      iconClass = service.iconClassForPath(@file.path, "tree-view")
if iconClass
  unless Array.isArray iconClass
    iconClass = iconClass.toString().split(/\s+/g)
  @fileName.classList.add(iconClass...)

```

7f09071 has me concerned Nuclide will eventually reimplement other Atom packages too, eventually introducing a change that's impossible to monkey-patch.. > With Nuclide this would be a non-starter, as one of the main focus areas for Nuclide is support for remote editing (on a remote host, that is).
Synchronous stat-calls are only made for detecting symlinks and deduping resources based on their inode. If the stat-call fails, the resource is assumed to be either unreadable or virtual, and marked as such. In which case, the package is instructed to avoid making an attempt to scan its contents.

Current approach in the file-tree is that everything that can be decided ahead of the rendering is, all data is kept in an immutable hierarchical data structure and the rendering is straightforward process from that structure.

If your rendering procedure is that restrictive, then it's better to use Atom's simpler icon-service. Anywhere in Nuclide where a [data-path] or [data-name] attribute is expected to show a file's icon should be instead using a call to the service hub.
Bottom line: the services API needs to be used one way or the other..

yurushao:
I got the version mismatch error after upgrading nuclide package in Atom to version 0.349.0
The server successfully started, but we were unable to connect.
Original error message:
 Version mismatch. Client at 349 while server at 341.
I tried sudo npm remove nuclide -g and sudo npm install nuclide -g but they didn't help.
I realized that there were two nuclide packages, /usr/lib/node_modules/nuclide (newer version) and /usr/local/lib/node_modules/nuclide (older version).
To fix the error, update the symbolic link nuclide-start-server and let it point to the latest version of file at /usr/lib/node_modules/nuclide/pkg/nuclide-server/nuclide-start-server..

su8hash:
Are you using physical device here ,You Need to be in same network and device should be able to connect to server (Android Steps Below)
1). If Using USB Debugging then run 'adb reverse tcp:8081 tcp:8081' from your "C:\Users\\AppData\Local\Android\sdk\platform-tools"
this will forward mobile's call for localhost:8081 to PC's localhost:8081,  here 8081 is port your server is running
2). If over Wifi on same network shake phone to open developer menu and go to 'Dev Setting' and enter Debug Server Host and Port  as :8081 here
I think this should help it does takes a few seconds sometime for app to load.

Nuclide's terminal does try to discover your default shell (as set by chsh on the target machine), but it is also possible to control explicitly. I just landed the documentation, so in case there is a delay in syncing to nuclide.io, here is the relevant section:
Custom Shell
By default, Nuclide terminal starts a new shell by running /bin/bash --login -i.  You can customize this behavior by adding a file $HOME/.nuclide-terminal.json on the machine where the shell process runs.  Here is an example you can use on OSX to start the version of bash from MacPorts:
{
  "command": [
    "/opt/local/bin/bash",
    "--login",
  ]
}.

CodeAn:
Sorry, I'm not too familiair with Ubuntu, command line, etc. 
But I think this is the info you need.
Path to node:
/root/.nvm/versions/node/v6.10.2/bin
$PATH variable:
echo $PATH
/root/.nvm/versions/node/v6.10.2/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games
However, when running whereis node, it shows:
/usr/bin/node
That path doesn't exist.
I tried to create a symbolic link to fix it, but it gives me a strange return.
ln -s /root/.nvm/versions/node/v6.10.2/bin /usr/bin/node
ln: failed to create symbolic link â/usr/bin/nodeâ: No such file or directory
Somehow it seems to add â anytime something is concerning /usr/bin/node. Also in the output file.
[edit]
There was a symbolic link from /usr/bin/node to /usr/bin/nodejs, I deleted this one.
Now whereis node shows nothing, that's progress I guess. 
I created a symlink to node
ln -s /root/.nvm/versions/node/v6.10.2/bin /usr/bin/node
When running the connect now, it gives me permission denied. 
So I tried changing the permissions:
cd /root/.nvm/versions/node/v6.10.2/bin
chmod +rx node
Only just now I noted that I installed nvm under the wrong directory... Which explains it all.
So I copied it, to where it belongs, and set approriate permissions.
n=$(which node); \
n=${n%/bin/node}; \
chmod -R 755 $n/bin/*; \
sudo cp -r $n/{bin,lib,share} /usr/local
I run it now and in an instant it works!.

. The extra code here just adds a single CSS attribute to the LI - it is shown highlighted in orange on the screenshot attached to the PR.  
A theme author could then do something like this
```css
.nuclide-outline-view span.icon {
  display: none;
}
.nuclide-outline-view .kind-property div {
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-position:  0 50%;
  background-image: url(data:image/png;base64,);
}
.nuclide-outline-view .kind-method div {
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-position:  0 50%;
  background-image: url(data:image/png;base64,);
}
.nuclide-outline-view span {
  padding-left: 5px
}
```
In the case shown there the icons are base64 encoded png's but they could be resources in the theme pack, jpg, gifs, svg etc.

That's fine.. @ssandler Thanks for reporting. What you've describe is actually just a small tip of the iceberg where the connection between Hack and Nuclide is inadequate. I've spent the past six months rewriting all of this connection code (inside both the Hack project and the Nuclide project). The resulting work is currently in beta-testing with a small group of users, and I'm expecting it to go out in the 3.23 hhvm release (Nov17).

The new code has much better "connection health monitoring". If hh_server isn't responding to Nuclide for any reason, then it shows why.
The new connection code is based on the standard "Language Server Protocol". That theoretically makes it easy to also do Hack development from other clients as well (such as VSCode, and plain vanilla Atom without the Nuclide package) although I haven't yet got around to writing extensions for them to support this.

So sorry to say that I don't think it's worth pursuing this issue in the current legacy hack/nuclide.
How to unblock you? Hmm... I'm not actually sure. I'm kind of hoping you can live with this unacceptable behavior for a few weeks longer.... Thanks for the pointer. Actually we're going for a slightly different approach. The way Pranay's plugin works is when VSCode asks for something e.g. "please show me hover at line 15 column 23" then it invokes a command-line utility hh_client --type-at-pos 15:23.
What we're doing is making hh_client lsp itself a native speaker of LSP. This means we have the ability to report stuff out-of-band (i.e. not solely in response to a request from VSCode). So for instance when hh_server stops, or is restarted, or is busy doing a typecheck, then the editor will show that straight away and can offer a "[Restart]" button when needed.
It also means that our LSP adapter has much easier access to the internals of hh_server. I'll be working to get Hack doc-comments into hover and autocomplete next month.. What I expect from other IDEs is that if there are these diagnostics
warning line20
error line26
error line15
then I can click on the Filename column header to sort by line number
error line15
warning line20
error line26
and then I can click on the Type column header so it sorts first by type and then within that it leaves the previous sort-by-line-number:
warning line20
error line15
error line26
But in Nuclide, when I click the Type column header, then it discards the previous sort-by-line-number. It produces this:
warning line20
error line26
error line15
. For what it's worth, Quip, Word, Excel and VS have the table-sorting memory I described. I didn't try any other table-presentation software.. Excel and Visual Studio indicate current sorting column with an arrow as you describe. I haven't yet tried IntelliJ or Eclipse. Word and Quip don't use a column, I guess because they're intended more for beautifully formatting an output document..

SuperCipher:
[solved]
Troubleshooting
when I tried node -v system return v8.4.0.
but once tried nodejs --version system return zsh: command not found: node using which nodejs and get no return is confirmed that system can't find NodeJS.
google around and found The "node" package is unrelated to "NodeJS".
Solution
Use n module from npm in order to upgrade node
```
sudo npm cache clean -f
sudo npm install -g n
sudo n stable
sudo ln -sf /usr/local/n/versions/node//bin/node /usr/bin/nodejs
```
. Thank @hansonw..

Following @TheBirdie 's advice, I built my own version from source.
```
Get pty src
git clone https://github.com/chjj/pty.js.git
cd pty.js/
Build pty
yarn install
Make missing dir from error, in my case /pty-v0.1.2-node-v59-linux-x64
mkdir /root/.nvm/versions/node/v9.6.1/lib/node_modules/nuclide/node_modules/nuclide-prebuilt-libs/pty/build/pty-v0.1.2-node-v59-linux-x64
Copy pty build to error dir
cp ./build/Release/pty.node /root/.nvm/versions/node/v9.6.1/lib/node_modules/nuclide/node_modules/nuclide-prebuilt-libs/pty/build/pty-v0.1.2-node-v59-linux-x64/pty.node 
```

After all that, the remote terminal seems to be working just fine, despite all of the pty deprecation warnings.
The reason this happens:

for this package we've only prebuilt binaries for Node versions corresponding to Electron versions corresponding to Atom versions (Phew!) Currently Atom 1.23/1.24 correspond to Node 7.4.0, and Atom 1.25 corresponds to Node 7.9.0, both of which are covered by this package.

If you aren't using a supported version of node, the nuclide prebuilt libs may not contain useable binaries for you.. Knowing that something is in the works is very good to know! ESlint is sorely missed in these remote projects, maybe this is a good architecture question for the atom crowd.. I totally feel your pain. I closed the issue because ESlint is its own organization, it's ultimately up to them or create their own ide language server like Facebook has with flow. 
I don't know of a more universal solution that Nuclide could facilitate. Running any linter on the remote box and reporting back the results via atom UI doesn't feel very vender agnostic.

awilkins:
Doesn't seem to be Atom-wide - doesn't happen with the core File Tree plugin, not seen it in any other panel.
If you start Atom with --clear-window-state it doesn't happen.
Also only happens in the "Folders" expansion, not in "Uncommitted Changes" or "Open Files".
If it's an Atom bug, something about the "Folders" region is triggering a real edge case.. That doesn't seem to work - Nuclide disables the native tree view anyway.
You can get it to resolve the issue temporarily by enabling the native tree view, then switching to that tab, and then back again, for the same reason I presume that folding / unfolding the "Folders" region in the Nuclide tree works - it redraws that element and the styles are actually applied.. @hansonw Nice detective work there ; props to you for knowing how to fix it as well.. Further detail

This also applies if a folder is above the selected file
If you close the editor for the selected file, and click the file or folder above it, the editor opens again - this seems to indicate that the click event is going to the same file element again. No console output. 

Have reproduced on all three of my machines

Ubuntu 16.04, Intel GPU
Ubuntu 16.04. nvidia GPU
Ubuntu 18.04. HiDPI screen, Intel GPU

Also reproduces when nuclide@0.299.0 is only non-core package installed (moved .atom and installed just Nuclide). 0.300.0 won't load right now.
Here you can see the displayed box model highlight for the <li> element for the .python-version file - covering the .node-version file above. That seems to be the issue - it's catching the clicks intended for .node-version, which explains why it re-opens the file if you close it's editor and try to click on .node-version 

. This seems to be a manifestation of a bug in one-dark-ui : #257.
Workaround : go to one-dark-ui settings and disable "Make tree-view project headers sticky".
This also gets rid of an annoying horizontal scrollbar at the base of the treeview.

. Aha. Looks like .getProjectDirectory() is available when the repo is a Mercurial repository.
Workaround / Patch :
Open pkg/nuclide-working-sets/lib/orkingSetsStore.js and replace getProjectDirectory() on line 177 with getWorkingDirectory().
Might break Mercurial support (seriously, who outside Facebook uses that....)  and might not have exactly the right effect when your checkout root isn't your project root but it's a quick edit and it seems to be OK for now.. xdissent:
I was facing this issue, but realized it had nothing to do with nuclide in my case. I use nodenv, and had globally installed flow-upgrade in a particular nodenv version. That seems to install a bin for the which pkg as well. With nodenv global bins, a shim is always installed in the PATH, regardless of whether the currently-active nodenv version contains the package. Running it from an incorrect nodenv version will just error with a message telling you which versions contain the actual pkg. On macOS, the native which is in /usr/bin, which is after the nodenv shims in my PATH. So nuclide was using the shim, but from a nodenv version without the which pkg. Potential fixes include adjusting the PATH, installing which in the correct nodenv version, or uninstalling flow-upgrade from all nodenv versions.
TL;DR - make sure nuclide is using the correct which bin..

kunokdev:
I had similar issue on both Linux and Mac. Both times searching for solution it led me to this issue, however I resolved it differently. So if someone gets similar problem; after fresh install of Nuclide, even tho flow works within terminal, but IDE can't find it, here is solution that solved it for me on both platforms.
First run this command to get path to Flow:
which flow
it should output something like this:
/usr/local/bin/flow
then on Ubuntu you can run vim ~/.bashrc or else on Mac you can run vim ~/.bash_profile to edit file in which you can extend PATH variable. If you don't like Vim, use anything else that can edit text.
Then add this line:
export PATH='$PATH:/usr/local/bin/flow'
Restart session and run echo $PATH and check if added line is included.
Alternatively, on Mac you can run sudo vim /etc/paths instead and add new line to that file with output from which flow .
TL;DR: add path to flow into PATH variable.

mkaminsky:
I'm seeing a similar problem on Linux with a HiDPI screen.  The fix mentioned above for Windows seems also to work for Linux.  I did a quick test and changed:
javascript
    if (_os.default.platform() === 'win32') {
to
javascript
    if (_os.default.platform() === 'win32' || _os.default.platform() === 'linux') {
and both the scrolling and extra wide button issues went away..

emanuelbsilva:
I did more research on the issue and found out the origin of it. It appears that the JSAutoImports autocomplete provider is not yielding any results for some reason and that makes Atom not being able to present any autocomplete results because it's still waiting for JSAutoImports i'm assuming.
Taking a close look at the https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/master/pkg/nuclide-js-imports-client/lib/main.js file i found out this code:
const lspService = await jsService.initializeLsp(
    ['.flowconfig'],
    ['.js'],
    (featureConfig.get('nuclide-js-imports-client.logLevel'): any),
    fileNotifier,
    host,
    getAutoImportSettings(),
  );
  return lspService || new NullLanguageService();
When i added '.es6' to the ['.js'] array autocomplete started working.
I think the best approach to solve the issue is to use whatever extension Atom's config.cson has registered for source.js.
  .

. I've got a workaround if anyone is interested:
1. Clone pty repo (https://github.com/chjj/pty.js)
2. cd pty && npm install
3. Create the folder missing from your error message (... ... nuclide/node_modules/nuclide-prebuilt-libs/pty/build/pty-v0.0.2-node-v59-linux-x64 for me)
4. Copy inside the binary generated in step (2) (pty.js/build/Release/pty.node)
.. or using an old NodeJS version corresponding to the ABI version 51 should work as well (see here https://nodejs.org/en/download/releases/).

Beside these dependencies errors in nuclide-debugger-common, there are also some issues with the types:
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/6046ad2ab91b9f77d14470dedd7a1d3b8ef965b0/modules/atom-ide-debugger-node/main.js#L42
In getNodeConfig in the node debugger atom-ide-debugger-node a AutoGenConfig is returned.
Unfortunately the returned value is actually incompatible with the type...
e.g. the property args has a defaultValue: [] but the AutoGenProperty only allows defaultValue?: string | number | boolean
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/6046ad2ab91b9f77d14470dedd7a1d3b8ef965b0/modules/nuclide-debugger-common/types.js#L114
Pls note that I have to use the published npm package nuclide-debugger-common (currently v0.7.0).
Compared to the current master commit this has already changed. Nice, but unfortunate that it has not been published to npm...
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/17dbd6ef9dda4c9afa31af601422cb1d0a9b18bc/modules/nuclide-debugger-common/types.js#L115
I have a feeling that the whole ecosystem around developing a debugger plugin for atom-ide-ui is not ready yet.... Also leaving aside these problem, I now have another problem.
As suggested I tried to model my debugger based on the atom-ide-debugger-node. It uses the AutoGenLaunchAttachProvider to create the config UI and start the debugger.
Unfortunately there is no way to provide my own adaperExecutable. Which (I assume) is the actual debug adapter.
https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/5aa45d09ea3caa0cd88215bbdd2e1fbe92c0ab27/modules/nuclide-debugger-common/AutoGenLaunchAttachUiComponent.js#L445

IMO options like adapterExecutable, capabilities and threadsComponentTitle should be configurable from the outside (and maybe have a meaningful default if none is provided).

arxanas:
The steps to fix were:

Install ocaml-language-server, such as with npm install -g ocaml-language-server.
Add a .merlin file to the root of the project directory.. If php-linter just relays the syntax errors from HHVM, then this will happen because HHVM doesn't support the double-arrow syntax in list expressions. I don't believe there are any plans to add it to HHVM, so you'll have to either not use this syntax or not use HHVM..

zenoCaiCai:
Pyg is only support python version from 2.5.0 to 3.0.0, so if you have the wrong version of python, you will meet this problem.
And if you have different versions of python, you will also meet this problem, which is because of node-gyp's stupid setup way:  node-gyp use a file called python-interceptor.sh to call your python program, and the command is static written in the sh file .
You may use python2.7 by command python2 in your shell, then you can use python2 in gyp too, by change "python" to "python2" in line37 and line40 in python-interceptor.sh(which can be found in your apm log), then problem solved.
See also https://github.com/danielgtaylor/atom-api-blueprint-preview/issues/38#issuecomment-430852308.

On Wed, Jul 25, 2018, 4:39 PM António Afonso notifications@github.com
wrote:

I've familiar with this issue and it hasn't been fixed.
The problem here is that the devices panel checks for the lock file for
each emulator and if it exists it assumes it's running. This is not a
reliable assumption because the lock file will not be removed when the
emulator is forced killed.
@csellis https://github.com/csellis a quick workaround is to remove the
lock file from ~/.android/avd/$DEVICE.avd/hardware-qemu.ini.lock.

Xanewok:
@jsgf I added a disclaimer (https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/pull/1606/commits/b948e1f1875b0e54d419891f02c6abab55a5c3d6) that warns the user to run the Buck build in a Rust project first. Is that desirable/okay for now?. > I hope we can get something more elegant in the longer term though.
Definitely, I am conviced this will not be an issue anymore once the RLS natively supports custom build systems.
Update: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/53870 has been merged and the newest Rust nightly (2018-09-04) contains the RLS binary supporting external simple build systems (needed for this) out of box, as well as external Rustfmt.. @mostafaeweda @jsgf Rebased and pushed two changes: one being displaying busy indicator while the Buck builds the save-analysis build and the other one working around a Buck bug (https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/pull/1606/commits/9f64faf40f56e04178c0af7feef7a298a3ae98bf), where outputs are relative to the cell, even when these are executed from the outer Buck root.
Does this still need more work or can we land it as the 1st increment?. @jsgf signed the CLA here, just in case.. This still requires explicit filtering for rust_* target kinds.. Done in https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/pull/1606/commits/8d4772f9ecda99b132d0f4b8eced16b9124455af. Forgot to remove the comment, sorry!. I understood that MultiLspLanguageService spawn separate LSP server per appropriate 'top-level' project config files like .hhconfig and that calling this seems like a good way to retrieve a handle to appropriate LSP server that's responsible for the fileUri we're building.
However, I did assume there's going to be a single Buck root; I'll see if it works with multiple ones.. It depends; using cargo check as example, complete check build can even take a minute or two; rechecking the leaf only shouldn't take longer than a couple of seconds. Third party deps are vendored and pre-compiled from what I understand, so this should also further cut down compilation time. @jsgf would know more about how long exactly these #save-analysis builds take in the Buck environment.
It would certainly be good to report the progress - do you know if it's possible to pass a callback or report the progress gracefully using the Buck API here?. Changed this to display a busy spinner indicator while the save-analysis build executes.. @mostafaeweda sorry it took so long! Just tested this with multiple buck roots, using https://github.com/Xanewok/rust-buck-skeleton and building both //server:server and nested//:nested. This correctly retrieved the LSP server at root dir and nested/, respectively, so this looks good so far =). It seems that we can't avoid at least one call here:
 getRustBuildFile is called to work around Buck cell-relative output bug (tested this with @jsgf, it seems that buildfile query is unaffected and always returns output relative to current Buck root and not the cell)
 getRustFiles already checks if it's a Rust target but we also need to get a representative file for which we get the LSP service
@mostafaeweda since the Buck cell bug will probably not be fixed quickly, do you think we can leave these 2 queries as it is, now?. @mostafaeweda my bad, I misunderstood what you were saying - I thought the gist was there being 2 calls and not checking before issuing them. Sorry! Will fix that in a moment.. Done here..
jsgf: @Xanewok I think its OK as a placeholder. I hope we can get something more elegant in the longer term though..

Is there some kind of log I can upload or diagnostic I can run to try to figure out where this is breaking down? I'm a longtime Vim user who's totally new to Atom/Nuclide, so unfortunately, I'm in the dark here. Any help would be appreciated..
